Jesse Jackson’s family vows to continue fight for justice, equality</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jy/" target="_blank" >Cindy Hernandez</a></h5><p><b>Family remembers</b>: Though Rev. Jesse Jackson was widely recognized as a civil rights icon, first and foremost he was a parent who "took fatherhood very seriously" and loved his family. That's how his children memorialized him Wednesday, sharing emotional tributes during a news conference outside the reverend’s South Shore home.</p><p><b>Funeral plans</b>: Family have scheduled Jackson’s funeral arrangements for next week. He will lie in state Feb. 25-26 at Rainbow PUSH’s Kenwood headquarters, 930 E. 50th St. A "People’s Celebration" will be held 10 a.m. Feb. 27 at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. Feb. 28 at Rainbow PUSH; doors open 9 a.m.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jj/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p></p><h4>RELIGION ✶</h4><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-7f0000" name="image-7f0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4a9d0b4/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6328x3551+0+334/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F64%2F328f741944dfaecc2006120be3fd%2Framadan-260219-013.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0dda989/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6328x3551+0+334/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F64%2F328f741944dfaecc2006120be3fd%2Framadan-260219-013.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/970e36c/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6328x3551+0+334/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fe0%2F64%2F328f741944dfaecc2006120be3fd%2Framadan-260219-013.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Mohamad Taisir Albik leads prayer to mark the end of the first day of Ramadan fasting at the Downtown Islamic Center of Chicago on Wednesday, Feb. 18, 2026. href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jt/" target="_blank" >Chicagoans lean on community, religion as Lent and Ramadan begin</a></h3><p></p><h5>By <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ji/" target="_blank" >Elleiana Green</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jd/" target="_blank" >Mohammad Samra</a>, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jh/" target="_blank" >Mary Norkol</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-jk/" target="_blank" >Violet Miller</a></h5><p><b>Ramadan starts</b>: The call to prayer echoed Wednesday night through a packed hall of the Downtown Islamic Center of Chicago as Muslims from across the area gathered to <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ju/" target="_blank" >break their first fast of Ramadan</a>. Silence fell as dozens bowed their heads in prayer before breaking their fast with dates and water. Ramadan, which began Tuesday evening, is observed by Muslims worldwide as a month of prayer, spiritual reflection and fasting from sunrise to sunset.</p><p><b>Renewed focus</b>: After prayer, worshippers came together for a communal meal and a renewed focus on safety, turning to each other for support amid heightened immigration enforcement. "A lot of us are children of immigrants, or [are] immigrants," said Rana Jaber, a board member at the center. "We let our community know that this is a safe space for them." </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-8a0000" name="image-8a0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0e97f60/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6820x3828+0+361/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffe%2F06%2F6d9662ad437ea456f50c8dd63f21%2Fashwednesday-260219-02.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/732dbb2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6820x3828+0+361/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffe%2F06%2F6d9662ad437ea456f50c8dd63f21%2Fashwednesday-260219-02.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/f9a5c73/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6820x3828+0+361/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffe%2F06%2F6d9662ad437ea456f50c8dd63f21%2Fashwednesday-260219-02.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Tom Dowling prays after receiving the imposition of ashes at Holy Name Cathedral on Ash Wednesday. Louis Cameli called for congregants to embrace repentance.</p><p><b>Broadview observances</b>: In suburban Broadview, <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-tr/" target="_blank" >faith leaders active in opposing the Trump administration’s immigration practices entered the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement center</a> after months of being denied access. A federal judge's ruling allowed the group to provide communion and ashes for services. </p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ty/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p> </p><h4>FROM THE PRESS BOX 🏀🏒⚾</h4><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="line-height: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 20px; margin-left: 24px; padding: 0px; list-style-type: disc;" id="rte-79930514-0da1-11f1-880b-272831a6a6d3"><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-tj/" target="_blank" ><b>Bulls press on</b></a>: As play continues tonight, the Bulls must approach the rest of the season with guarded optimism, writes Joe Cowley.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-tt/" target="_blank" ><b>Hawks back at it</b></a>: The Blackhawks debuted an adjusted defensive system in their first practice after the Olympic break.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ti/" target="_blank" ><b>Pereira’s potential</b></a>: Everson Pereira, who the White Sox acquired from Tampa Bay, is showing potential early in spring camp.<br></li><li><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-td/" target="_blank" ><b>New union boss</b></a>: Bruce Meyer was promoted to interim executive director of the baseball players’ association Wednesday. </div> </div><p></p><h3><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ir/" target="_blank" >Lincoln Park Zoo welcomes Qi the red panda</a></h3><p></p><h5>Reporting by <a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-iy/" target="_blank" >Elleiana Green</a></h5><p>Lincoln Park Zoo has welcomed its newest resident: Qi, a 7-year-old red panda brought to the zoo for a ‘species survival plan.’</p><p>Qi arrived from New York’s Prospect Park Zoo nearly a month ago and had been in quarantine until Friday, when he was placed in his permanent habitat at Lincoln Park Zoo.</p><p>Since his arrival, Qi has made himself right at home, said Cassy Kutilek, curator of large mammals and carnivores.</p><p>Qi, who was brought to Lincoln Park Zoo on a breeding recommendation, will be a new mate for Nisha, an 8-year-old female red panda who has been there several years. Kutilek says the arrival is perfectly timed, as red pandas typically breed between January and March.</p><p>On Tuesday, the pair met for the first time, and Kutilek says they seem to be compatible based on their genetics and behaviors.</p><p>"So far, it’s been a love connection," Kutilek said.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ij/" target="_blank" ><b>READ MORE</b></a></p><hr><p>Thanks for reading the Sun-Times Morning Edition!<br>Got a story you think we missed? <a class="Link" href="mailto:newsletters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >Email us here.</a></p><hr><p><b>Written and curated by</b>: Matt Moore<br><b>Editor</b>: Eydie Cubarrubia</p><hr><p><i>The Chicago Sun-Times is a nonprofit supported by readers like you. Become a member to make stories like these free and available to everyone. Learn more at </i><a class="Link" href="https://newsletters.suntimes.com/t/t-l-wjrduiy-l-ii/" target="_blank" ><i>suntimes.com/member</i></a><i>.</i></p>

entries.title: 2 killed, 3 injured in rollover crash on Bishop Ford on Far South Side
entries.summary: <p>A vehicle flipped early Thursday on the inbound Bishop Ford Freeway, leaving two people dead and three hurt early Thursday on the Bishop Ford Freeway on the Far South Side. </p><p>The crash happened around 1:15 a.m. near 111th Street, Illinois state police said. Two occupants of the vehicle were pronounced dead at the scene and three others were hospitalized with injuries. </p><p>All northbound lanes were still shut down and traffic was being diverted at 115th Street, state police said.</p><p>Further information was not immediately available. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Boy, 16, shot in Chicago Lawn
entries.summary: <p>A 16-year-old boy is recovering after being shot in the knee Wednesday night in Chicago Lawn on the Southwest Side. </p><p>The teen was outside in the 7100 block of South Albany Avenue around 8:35 p.m. when he was shot in the knee, Chicago police said. </p><p>He was taken to Comer Children's Hospital where he was in good condition, police said. </p><p>No one was in custody. </p>
entries.author: Sun-Times Wire

entries.title: Trump administration slashes away at science, but scientists are pushing back
entries.summary: <p>My father had one good idea.</p><p>Okay, that is unfair. He had many good ideas. Marrying my mom, for starters. He also held patents in the design of compact nuclear reactors.</p><p>In fact, those two good ideas might be related — there was a shakedown cruise of an atomic-powered submarine that my father, a naval reservist, was keen to avoid. Married men were exempt. Perhaps it's cynical of me to connect them.</p><p>But he also had one really good idea that resonated around the world and has an impact today.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-860000" name="module-860000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Opinion bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Opinion</h2></div> </div><p>My father's really good idea occurred to him in the early 1970s. The 747 Jumbo Jet had been introduced, to endless publicity — the spiral staircase leading to the lounge in the bulging upper deck hump, the enormous capacity, 400 passengers, making long haul air travel economical for millions. And — what my father noticed — radar systems and other instruments that monitored atmospheric conditions around the plane. A constant stream of data.</p><p><i>You know</i> ... Robert Steinberg thought ...<i>what if that weather data wasn't just used to fly the plane? What if it was sent to a central location? And then used ... to predict the weather?</i></p><p>It would be a big improvement over weather stations — scattered mountaintop outposts, with thermometers and spinning anemometers and such. Plus weather balloons, instrument packages floated high into the upper atmosphere for expensive keyhole glimpses.</p><p>He wrote an article titled, "Role of Commercial Aircraft in Global Monitoring Systems," that ran in the April 27, 1973 issue of <i>Science</i>.</p><p>"The new family of wide-bodied jets such as the 747, DC-10, and L-1011 aircraft can be used to supply important global atmospheric and tropical meteorological data for which there is a pressing need," my father wrote. "In the final analysis, commercial aircraft may offer the most inexpensive way to monitor our atmosphere in the near future."</p><p>By summer, NASA loaned him out to NCAR — the National Center for Atmospheric Research — in Boulder, Colorado. NCAR was in a stunning, I.M. Pei-designed building of reddish concrete. Boulder was nice. Mountains. He traveled the world, signing up airlines. The idea took hold. </p><p>"Aircraft-based observations play a big role in the accuracy of weather forecasts — reducing forecast errors in numerical weather prediction systems by up to 10%" according to the World Meterological Association.</p><p>This is a long way of saying that, in an era of constant shocks to American science — 25,000 federal researchers and support staff left the government this past year, thousands of grants slashed, agencies shuttered, scientific data yanked off line, the U.S. scientific establishment being "systematically destroyed" in the words of the Union of Concerned Scientists, NCAR being scuttled stood out as personal. </p><p>And political. NCAR is being closed down by the Trump administration for the sin of "climate alarmism." Because atmospheric research points to uncomfortable facts that business and its handmaiden, government, don't want to think about anymore.</p><p>We should be clear why all of this is happening. Business makes money, but if it has to, oh, consider pollution, or worry about the purity of food or the efficacy of drugs, it makes less money. So watchdog agencies, and research facilities and university centers that would counterbalance the whims of business are being scrapped.</p><p>Scientists are not going quietly.</p><p>"Our group in Chicago has grown, hosting teach-ins, talks at public libraries, and community events around the city," said Anna Vlasits, a University of Illinois Chicago neurobiologist who last year helped organize the city's <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2025/03/02/donald-trump-federal-funding-freeze-science-researchers-national-institutes-of-health" target="_blank" >“Stand Up for Science”</a> rally on Federal Plaza.</p><p>"Science is important." she said. "It brings us knowledge. We need government to be involved, to support scientific research and training in this country."</p><p>How has the past year been?</p><p>"It feels a little bit like playing Whac-a-Mole — so much is going on that's not good," she said. "Young scientists being turned away from the United States is profoundly bad and alarming. The U.S. is a powerhouse training scientists, globally, and now we're losing people who are concerned about being an immigrant, or worried about whether their work will be funded."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2025/03/02/donald-trump-federal-funding-freeze-science-researchers-national-institutes-of-health" >Chicago scientists reel from Trump funding cuts: ‘We are just going to abandon all those discoveries’</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>I wondered whether she knew about NCAR, or whether it was a private heartbreak. She did.</p><p>"The supercomputer at NCAR being privatized," said Vlasits. "They're generally taking the whole center apart. A lot of climate data is now owned by companies, so they can take advantage of knowing what's happening with global climate in a way individuals can't."</p><p>The next "Stand Up for Science" rally will be Saturday, March 7 at 1 p.m. on Federal Plaza. I was at last year's rally, a cold, blustery, wet day, and hoped the weather wouldn't be as bad this time.</p><p>"I hope not," she said. "It's hard to say. Maybe we won't know if we're not monitoring the weather anymore."</p>
entries.author: Neil Steinberg

entries.title: Rev. Jesse Jackson took on Hollywood 20 years before #OscarsSoWhite
entries.summary: <p>Nearly 20 years before Black Twitter’s #OscarsSoWhite campaign generated a firestorm over the lack of Black nominees at the Academy Awards, Rev. Jesse Jackson lit a spark with a call to protest the 1996 ceremony.</p><p>That year, just one Black person, short film director Dianne Houston, was included among 166 nominees.</p><p>“We are going to open up the consciousness of Hollywood,” <a class="Link" href="https://www.latimes.com/archives/la-xpm-1996-03-22-me-50083-story.html" target="_blank" ><u>said Jackson</u></a>, who <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" >died at 84 on Tuesday.</a> The Chicago civil rights leader called for attendees to wear a symbol against “race exclusion and cultural violence” in Hollywood, and others to picket outside of ABC-TV affiliates in Chicago and other cities.</p><p>Ultimately, the protest faltered, and Jackson was criticized by the academy, viewers and other industry insiders, including Black actors who attended the event. But the civil rights leader’s critiques proved prescient amid the public outcry over the 2015 and 2016 ceremonies, which did not recognize any actors of color in the acting categories.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-110000" name="image-110000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/68aa3ca/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3077x1727+0+236/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Fa2%2Fb4b9b4bc4cb498db8ba115b57a10%2Fap369063958682.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4feec63/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3077x1727+0+236/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Fa2%2Fb4b9b4bc4cb498db8ba115b57a10%2Fap369063958682.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Jesse Jackson, Betty Shabazz, Tom Todd, Aretha Franklin, Louis Stokes" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4feec63/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3077x1727+0+236/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Fa2%2Fb4b9b4bc4cb498db8ba115b57a10%2Fap369063958682.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/28a470d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3077x1727+0+236/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Fa2%2Fb4b9b4bc4cb498db8ba115b57a10%2Fap369063958682.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/4feec63/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3077x1727+0+236/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Fa2%2Fb4b9b4bc4cb498db8ba115b57a10%2Fap369063958682.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rev. Jesse Jackson speaks to reporters at the Operation PUSH Soul Picnic at the 142nd Street Armory in New York, March 26, 1972. Left to right are: Betty Shabazz, behind Jackson, widow of Malcolm X; Jackson; Tom Todd, vice president of PUSH; Aretha Franklin and Louis Stokes. Jackson had an outsized impact on American culture and the inclusion of Black film in Hollywood.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Jim Wells/AP</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>By contrast, at this year’s forthcoming Academy Awards, multiple actors of color are up for trophies, with Black director Ryan Coogler's film "Sinners" garnering 16 nominations, making it the <a class="Link" href="https://ew.com/sinners-makes-oscars-history-with-most-nominations-for-one-movie-11890251" target="_blank" ><u>most-Oscar-nominated movie</u></a> in history. </p><p>Reflecting on the progress since Jackson’s early advocacy, industry veterans and young filmmakers alike are celebrating Jackson for not only raising awareness about inequities in Hollywood, but also the actions he took to create opportunities for Black filmmakers and entertainers.</p><p>“He was always focusing on these questions of equity and leadership, and that's what he was bringing to the Oscars campaign,” said <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2025/07/30/south-side-home-movie-project-university-chicago-depicts-family-lives-8-mm" >Jacqueline Stewart</a>, a cinema and media studies professor at the University of Chicago and former director and president of the Academy Museum of Motion Pictures in Los Angeles.</p><p>“He was bringing visibility to the issue even though people had mixed responses. But, without a doubt, it created the kind of cultural conversation that eventually did lead the academy to make some important changes.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/columnists/2026/02/18/lights-camera-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-pop-culture-presence" >Lights, camera, Jackson: Civil Rights leader also became a pop culture presence</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/17/what-we-know-rev-jesse-jacksons-death-services" >What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson’s death and next week’s services to honor him</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-chicago-mayors-a-fraught-and-contentious-relationship" >Rev. Jesse Jackson and Chicago mayors — a tense, fraught relationship</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/photos-jesse-jackson-through-the-years" >Photos: Jesse Jackson through the years</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Prior to his Academy Awards protest, Jackson formed the Rainbow Coalition on Fairness in the Media, demanding that studio and network executives hire more people of color and support diverse films and TV shows. But the movement <a class="Link" href="https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/tv/story/2026-02-17/jesse-jackson-hollywood-diversity" target="_blank" ><u>failed to gain momentum</u></a>. Later, he struggled to generate support at the 1996 Oscars in part because the ceremony featured two prominent Black participants that people wanted to support: producer Quincy Jones and host Whoopi Goldberg, who poked fun at Jackson from the stage.</p><p>Still, Jackson should be credited with sounding the alarm about marginalization in the industry, said Michael NJ Wright, a filmmaker and adjunct professor of instruction at Columbia College Chicago.</p><p>“There was this attitude that Black people made Black movies, women made women's movies, and white men made everything,” Wright said. “It was just an understanding of the way the movie business functioned.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-da0000" name="image-da0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/87b7108/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b61b14f/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7b04f5e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg" alt="MNJW@ Op. Push w_Rev.Jackson 2.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7b04f5e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/eaafde2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/7b04f5e/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2995x1681+90+0/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ff1%2Fd0%2Fb0958ed5470dace71b0f912172b3%2Fmnjw-op-push-w-rev-jackson-2.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Michael NJ Wright (far right), a filmmaker and adjunct professor of instruction at Columbia College Chicago, poses with Rev. Jesse Jackson (seated) during a panel at the Operation PUSH Headquarters in Chicago in 2024.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Michaeal NJ Wright</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>But others picked up where Jackson left off two years later, when the academy failed to nominate any people of color for acting awards. As one of few artists of color recognized in other categories, Spike Lee spoke out about the oversight.</p><p>“Until the academy actually starts to recruit younger members and there is more diversity in it, I don't see a change happening,” Lee said at the time. The director was nominated for his documentary “4 Little Girls.”</p><p>“I just think that as a whole, with African American artists in front and behind the camera, the academy has been slow to recognize their work," he said.</p><p>Former Sun-Times film critic Richard Roeper also wrote a column criticizing the awards for overlooking Black artists, citing performances in "Amistad," "Soul Food" and "Eve’s Bayou" as worthy of recognition.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-690000" name="image-690000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/3ba1e1b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/0b4b617/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/78b327b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="A 1972 clip from the Chicago Sun-Times forecasts plans for a culture-focused convention. Sun-Times archives" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/78b327b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/629aa10/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/78b327b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/4000x2245+0+378/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F05%2Fe1%2F8b7721b146489a8899405266e2bf%2Funtitled-design-11.png" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>A 1972 clip from the Chicago Sun-Times forecasts plans for a culture-focused convention.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Sun-Times archives</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“Scanning the list, I'm wondering if Jackson's publicity blitz didn't come a couple of years too soon,” he wrote. “This year more than ever, he could have made the argument that the academy has neglected African Americans who should have been honored.”</p><p>The conversation was revived decades later, when attorney-turned-media strategist April Reign spearheaded the <a class="Link" href="https://www.rollingstone.com/tv-movies/tv-movie-features/oscars-so-white-10-years-1235276085/" target="_blank" >#OscarSoWhite social media movement</a>. In 2016, prominent Hollywood players Spike Lee, Jada Pinkett Smith and Will Smith boycotted the ceremony. And the same year, Cheryl Boone Isaacs, the first Black female president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, made a commitment to increase the number of women and people of color in the groups voting membership.</p><p>Jackson praised the changes in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2016/02/01/jesse-jackson-hollywood-oscars-diversity/79614066/" target="_blank" ><u>2016 opinion piece in USA Today</u></a>,<b> </b>but called for more diversity in leadership positions at studios.</p><p>“The lack of diversity starts long before the stars pose and parade on the red carpet come Oscar night,” he wrote. “Open your eyes, Hollywood. It’s time to flip the script.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-de0000" name="image-de0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/50f30d2/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/17e4b6d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6980157/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Halle Berry, Rev. Jesse Jackson" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6980157/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ef53569/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6980157/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2296x1289+0+856/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F6c%2F83%2F1d5beeb54530b97528ff0dd68543%2Fap070222037734.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Halle Berry, left, and the Rev. Jesse Jackson laugh together at the 2007 Ebony Magazine pre-Oscars celebration in Los Angeles, Thursday, Feb. 22, 2007. Berry was honored at the event. (AP Photo/Matt Sayles)</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Matt Sayles/ASSOCIATED PRESS</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Jackson's efforts have inspired up-and-coming filmmakers such as jada-amina, who is also the curator of the Black Harvest Film Festival in Chicago.</p><p>“He was challenging how wealth and opportunity really circulate in the industry,” she said.</p><p>The greatest lesson she learned from Jackson was self-reliance, she said.</p><p>“The response to the blighting in Hollywood of Black stories is to create our own movement," she said.</p><p>Jackson himself showcased the value of independence, creating opportunities for Black filmmakers and entertainers during the 1972 Black Expo in Chicago. Hosted at the International Amphitheater by his Operation PUSH organization, the five-day business, arts and culture event drew more than a million attendees. </p><p>From the Temptations and the Jackson Five to Nancy Wilson and the Staple Singers, Jackson helped recruit a wealth of Black talent to perform. The event was documented by director Stan Lathan in a film, "<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2024/10/18/save-the-children-chicago-jesse-jackson-stan-lathan-1972-black-expo-sammy-davis-jr" >Save the Children</a>." A digitally restored version is streaming on Netflix.</p><p>"They had Black cameramen at a time when it was very difficult for Black people to get into the unions," Stewart said. "[Jackson] was so committed to Black agency and autonomy and self-determination, and he brought that into every interaction that he had with film and film-making." </p><p>That influence has carried on in Black filmmakers like Chicago native <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/movies-and-tv/2025/12/02/robert-townsend-chicago-film-festival-columbia-college-cultural-center" >Robert Townsend</a>, who famously directed, produced and financed his debut film, "Hollywood Shuffle."</p><p>“My heart hurts today with the passing of the civil rights legend Rev. Jesse Jackson," Townsend told the Sun-Times in a statement. "As the pendulum swings backwards in these trying times, he is a constant reminder of the movement he helped start and put his life on the line for. May God bless his soul. I pray for his family at this time and lift them up.”</p><p>Jackson's life is also a reminder that justice is not always immediate, Wright said. </p><p>"He chipped away at many of these institutions that were impediments, and then we get progress," he said. "Maybe not the generation that we lived, but future generations enjoy it."</p>
entries.author: Erica Thompson

entries.title: Bears name Jeff King assistant GM
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> promoted Jeff King from senior player personnel director to assistant general manager on Thursday, giving GM Ryan Poles a new deputy.</p><p>King replaces Ian Cunningham, who earlier this month was named the GM of the Falcons.<br>When Poles took the Bears job four years ago, he created the position of assistant GM and picked Cunningham for the job.</p><p>King has been part of some of the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/18/bears-make-4-coaching-hires-official-ben-johnson-press-taylor-eric-studesville-will-lawing-isaiah-ford-nfl" target="_blank" >Bears</a>’ biggest decisions in recent years — and was on the search committee that picked head coach Ben Johnson one year ago.</p><p>As a tight end, King was a fifth-round pick of the Panthers, where he caught 60 passes for<br>802 yards over four years. He was hired as a Bears scouting intern in 2015 and climbed the ranks, being promoted a pro scout, then assistant pro scouting director, then pro scouting director. He and Trey Koziol shared the title of co-player personnel director before King was named senior player personnel director in June 2024.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Hammond Bears? Team says Indiana site near Wolf Lake is now their main stadium focus
entries.summary: <p>The Hammond Bears?</p><p>Indiana state legislators sure seem to think that’s where <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium" >Chicago’s football team is headed</a> — though the team stopped short of committing to pulling up stakes from Illinois and moving across the border.</p><p>An Indiana House committee advanced legislation Thursday creating a stadium finance authority that would help the team build a stadium in northwest Indiana, a move that the team called “the most meaningful step forward” in a saga that has stretched on for about three years.</p><p>Indiana House Speaker Todd Huston said he wouldn’t call the Bears legislation that passed the state Senate last month without a commitment from the team that they’ll make the move.</p><p>He apparently heard enough to bring it to his chamber's Ways & Means Committee, which unanimously passed the measure during a jovial hearing that saw some officials, including Hammond Mayor Thomas McDermott, tear up — though no team official addressed the panel directly.</p><p>“I think we found a great partner in the Chicago Bears,” Huston said. “Today is a historic day, one we look forward to building upon.”</p><p>McDermott said “Hammond's ready to partner with the state of Indiana. Hammond's ready to partner with the Chicago Bears — basically, Hammond will do whatever it takes to help make this project a success.”</p><p>Huston read a statement from the Bears, asserting the Indiana bill’s passage “would mark the most meaningful step forward in our stadium planning efforts to date. We are committed to finishing the remaining site-specific necessary due diligence to support our vision to build a world-class stadium near the Wolf Lake area in Hammond, Indiana.”</p><p>A Bears spokesman said “Hammond is the site we are focused on. Work to be done.”</p><p>That wouldn’t appear to rule out the team’s long-coveted move to Arlington Heights, one of three places the team has pointed its focus to over the past few years, along with Chicago and Hammond.</p><p>Complaining of a lack of legislative partnership in their current home state, the Bears announced in December they were looking at Indiana as a potential destination, visiting several spots with NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell last month.</p><p>The movement <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/01/16/chicago-bears-stadium-northwest-indiana-arlington-heights-jb-pritzker-kam-buckner" >appeared to spur some action in Springfield</a>, where the team is seeking legislation that would allow them to negotiate payments with local taxing bodies in lieu of paying full property taxes.</p><p>An Illinois House panel had been set for a hearing on such legislation Thursday, but the committee canceled the meeting.</p><p>Gov. JB Pritzker, who has supported the prospect of publicly funding infrastructure projects to support a stadium, has expressed optimism in ongoing negotiations with the team.</p><p>“I think that progress has been made,” he said Wednesday, after delivering his annual State of the State address.</p><p>Other sources close to the Arlington Heights negotiations were also optimistic about the direction of talks.</p><p>A Pritzker spokesperson on Thursday said "Illinois was ready to move this bill forward. After a productive three hour meeting yesterday, the Bears leaders requested the ILGA pause the hearing to make further tweaks to the bill. This morning, we were surprised to see a statement lauding Indiana and ignoring Illinois."</p><p>The Indiana bill would empower a newly created Northwest Indiana Stadium Authority to build a stadium for the Bears and sell it to the team for $1 once the 40-year bonds are paid off. The Bears would also have the option to buy the Indiana stadium sooner by retiring the outstanding debt.</p><p>In the meantime, the Bears would sign a 35-year lease that would allow the team to retain all revenues generated by the stadium.</p><p>Hoosier lawmakers are aiming to pass it by the end of the month. Illinois lawmakers are in session through May.</p><p>Indiana Gov. Mike Braun trumpeted his state’s progress with the team, saying their legislation “puts forward the essential framework to complete this agreement, contingent upon site due diligence proceeding smoothly.</p><p>“The State of Indiana moves at the speed of business, and we’ve demonstrated that through our quick coordination between state agencies, local government, and the legislature to set the stage for a huge win for all Hoosiers,” Braun said in a social media post. “We have built a strong relationship with the Bears organization that will serve as the foundation for a public-private partnership, leading to the construction of a world-class stadium and a win for taxpayers.”</p>
entries.author: Mitchell Armentrout

entries.title: U.S. takes gold with 2-1 OT victory over Canada in Olympic women's hockey final
entries.summary: <p>MILAN — United States wins its third Olympic gold medal in women's hockey, beating Canada 2-1 on Megan Keller's goal in overtime.</p><p>U.S. captain Hilary Knight prolonged her final game at the Olympics by sending the game to overtime.</p><p>Knight deflected Laila Edwards’ shot past Ann-Renee Desbiens with 2:04 left in regulation and the U.S. skating 6 on 5 with goaltender Aerin Frankel pulled for an extra attacker. The goal was her 15th at the Olympics, the most in team history.</p><p>Canada had led since Kristin O’Neill scored short-handed less than a minute into the second period, ending the U.S. shutout streak at 352 minutes, 17 seconds. Desbiens and Frankel went save for save in a back-and-forth game that was far more competitive than the rivals’ first meeting in the preliminary round, when the U.S. routed Canada 5-0.</p><p>The Americans romped through the tournament, outscoring opponents 31-1.</p><p>The U.S. and Canada have met in all but one Olympic final — the 2006 Turin Games won by Canada — since women's hockey made its debut at the 1998 Nagano Games.</p><p>Knight, 36, has already announced these will be her U.S.-record fifth and final Games, with a second gold medal to go with her three silvers. The game was played a day after Knight proposed to U.S. speedskater Brittany Bowe.</p><p>The defending Olympic champion Canadians have shown signs of age during a tournament in which they lost 5-0 to the Americans in the preliminary round, and eked into the final with a 2-1 win over Switzerland.</p><p>Switzerland beat Sweden in overtime in the the bronze medal game on another clutch goal by Alina Muller.<br></p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: Lo que sabemos sobre la muerte del Rev. Jesse Jackson y los servicios para honrarlo
entries.summary: <p>"Todos son bienvenidos" a los servicios programados para el Reverendo Jesse Jackson, un ícono de Chicago conocido por su trabajo como líder de los derechos civiles, quien <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/17/el-reverendo-jesse-jackson-abrio-el-camino-para-generaciones-de-democratas-en-chicago-e-illinois" target="_blank" >“falleció pacíficamente” a los 84 años</a>, dijo su familia durante una conferencia de prensa el martes por la mañana.</p><p></p><h3>¿Cuándo son los servicios fúnebres?</h3><p>Jesse Jackson será velado el miércoles <b>25 de febrero</b> y el jueves <b>26 de febrero</b> en la sede de Rainbow PUSH en el vecindario de Kenwood, ubicada en el 930 E. 50th St. Una "Celebración del Pueblo" se llevará a cabo en House of Hope, en el 752 E. 114th St. a las 10 a.m. del viernes <b>27 de febrero</b>.</p><p>Los servicios de despedida están programados para las 10 a.m. del sábado <b>28 de febrero</b> en Rainbow PUSH. Las puertas abrirán a las 9 a.m.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-9b0000" name="module-9b0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Los familiares de Jackson dijeron que "todos son bienvenidos", sin importar el partido político.</p><p>"No traigan su política, por respeto al Reverendo Jesse Jackson y a la vida que vivió, a estos servicios de despedida. Vienen con respeto y vienen a decir gracias", dijo Jesse Jackson Jr. durante un evento mediático frente a la casa de la familia Jackson. "Pero en estos servicios de despedida todos son bienvenidos: demócratas, republicanos, liberales y conservadores, de la derecha y de la izquierda, porque su vida es lo suficientemente amplia como para abarcar todo el espectro de lo que significa ser estadounidense".</p><p>Considerado como el protegido del Reverendo Martin Luther King Jr., Jackson trabajó incansablemente durante el Movimiento por los Derechos Civiles y después para abogar por los derechos de las personas negras. Fundó la Coalición Rainbow PUSH, la famosa organización sin fines de lucro multirracial con sede en Chicago, en 1970, y continúa luchando por el cambio social, la igualdad económica y los derechos civiles. En la década de 1980, Jackson dirigió la primera campaña presidencial viable de un candidato negro en Estados Unidos.</p><p>Tras su muerte, líderes de todo el mundo y residentes de Chicago han compartido mensajes de apoyo para la familia, recordando a Jackson por sus años de activismo mientras lloran su pérdida.</p><h3>¿Cómo murió?</h3><p>Aunque la familia no ha dado una causa oficial de muerte ni ha dicho dónde falleció, Jackson había estado en declive de salud durante una década antes de su muerte. En 2015, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" target="_blank" >se le diagnosticó inicialmente con la enfermedad de Parkinson</a>, pero reveló el pasado abril que en realidad se trataba de una parálisis supranuclear progresiva.</p><h3>¿Cómo está reaccionando el mundo político ante su muerte?</h3><p>Figuras políticas de todo el país han expresado sus condolencias y honrado su legado.</p><p>En un comunicado conjunto, el expresidente Barack Obama y la exprimera dama Michelle Obama escribieron: "Michelle y yo siempre estaremos agradecidos por la vida de servicio de Jesse y la amistad que nuestras familias comparten. Nos apoyamos en sus hombros. Enviamos nuestras más profundas condolencias a la familia Jackson y a todos en Chicago y más allá que lo conocieron y lo amaron".</p><p>El presidente Donald Trump también extendió sus condolencias a la familia de Jackson en un comunicado publicado en Truth Social el martes.</p><p>"Lo conocí bien, mucho antes de ser presidente", dijo. "Era muy extrovertido, ¡una persona que realmente amaba a la gente! A pesar de que me llaman falsamente y de manera consistente racista por los sinvergüenzas y lunáticos de la izquierda radical, TODOS demócratas, siempre fue un placer ayudar a Jesse en su camino".</p><p>Líderes de Chicago, incluyendo al alcalde Brandon Johnson y al gobernador JB Pritzker, también compartieron sus condolencias.</p><p>"En honor al servicio del Rev. Jackson, y mientras nuestra ciudad llora, la bandera de Chicago será izada a media asta", escribió el alcalde Johnson en un comunicado.</p><p>Pritzker también ordenó que todas las banderas del estado ondeen a media asta en honor a él en un comunicado publicado en las redes sociales.</p><p>"Rompió barreras, inspiró generaciones y mantuvo viva la esperanza. Nuestro estado, nación y mundo son mejores gracias a sus años de servicio", dijo Pritzker.</p><h3>¿Cómo están reaccionando los residentes de Chicago ante su muerte?</h3><p>En toda la ciudad, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-chicago-remembers" target="_blank" >los residentes de Chicago lamentaron la muerte de Jackson</a> y pidieron que su legado continúe.</p><p>Martin Travis, congregante de la Iglesia Apostólica de Dios en Woodlawn, dijo que en su juventud, sus padres lo llevaban a las manifestaciones organizadas por Operation Breadbasket, un grupo liderado por Jackson.</p><p>Ahora, a sus 64 años, Travis recuerda a Jackson como "fundamental en la lucha por la justicia y la libertad para todas las personas".</p><p>Chloe Gould, de 41 años y residente de Bronzeville, dijo que su muerte todavía le impacta "como si hubieras perdido a un miembro de la familia".</p><p>Tras su muerte, comentó que le preocupa el futuro del activismo por los derechos civiles, ya que activistas y líderes no han asumido el papel que él dejó.</p><p>"¿Quién va a ser el activista de derechos civiles ahora?", preguntó.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: How Jack Silverstein became Chicago's sports historian
entries.summary: <p>In the summer of 2010, Jack Silverstein was chatting with friends at a Wicker Park bar when the subject turned to his writing.</p><p>That March, he had published a book, “Our President,” a series of essays about Barack Obama. He was covering the Chicago music scene heavily for several outlets. But two of his buddies offered a suggestion.</p><p>They told Silverstein that he should write about sports. They acknowledged his writing chops but said he reached another level when he wrote about sports.</p><p>“I thought sports was too easy,” Silverstein said this week. “Maybe in a sense I was looking down on it. It came so naturally to me that I thought nothing this easy can be worthwhile. What I found was, I was terribly wrong.”</p><p>Silverstein loved sports, especially Chicago sports. He grew up on the North Shore in the 1980s, when the Bears and Bulls were rising to power and the Cubs were returning to relevance. Sportswriting might have come easy for him, but there was a way to make it challenging and make his work stand out — become Chicago’s sports historian.</p><p>“That’s a self-applied title,” Silverstein said. “My father always said, ‘Let them put you in a box,’ meaning help people know who you are. I love history, I love sports. I thought that was good branding. I thought ‘Chicago sports historian’ was crisp and gave me something it live up to.”</p><p>Which he has. Silverstein, 44, has broken news retroactively. In 2019, when the Bears had Kyle Fuller and Tarik Cohen model 1936 throwback uniforms, Silverstein discovered they were the first Black players to wear them because the NFL had banned Black players from 1934 to ’45. His research drew not just the Bears’ attention, but the late Jesse Jackson’s, and the story was picked up by ESPN, Fox and even the BBC.</p><p>In 2021, Silverstein led the Bears to correct their record book, making “Chuckin’ ” Charlie O’Rourke the then-record holder for touchdown passes by a rookie with 11 in 1942. When Caleb Williams broke it with 20 in 2024, O’Rourke received his long-overdue recognition.</p><p>Silverstein has appeared on Chicago radio, TV and podcasts. His work appears on the website Windy City Gridiron and his own site, A Shot On Ehlo, named in honor of Michael Jordan’s buzzer-beating, playoff-series-winning shot over the Cavaliers’ Craig Ehlo in 1989. Late Bulls radio voice Jim Durham said the words “a shot on Ehlo” on his call.</p><p>Silverstein’s Bulls research has led to his 2016 e-book “How the GOAT Was Built: 6 Life Lessons From the 1996 Chicago Bulls,” and the series of posts on his website are leading to his book, “6 Rings: The Bulls, The City, and the Dynasty that Changed the Game.”</p><p>“[‘How the GOAT Was Built’] was really important because it formalized my position as a sports historian,” Silverstein said, “and it gave me something I could do shows on.”</p><p>All of this work isn’t even Silverstein’s job. By day, he’s the director of content at WTWH Media, where he covers the business of senior living. By night, he’s researching and writing about sports.</p><p>“I just write a lot. I have a gear,” said Silverstein, who’s married with two kids. “There’s no good way to explain it. I have a gear that just goes. If I didn’t get these stories out, I would break down.”</p><p>Former Sun-Times columnist Rick Telander noticed that gear early. As a sophomore at New Trier, Silverstein hosted a radio show and asked Telander to be a guest. Telander appeared and then invited Silverstein to sit in on a recording of the beloved show “The Sportswriters on TV.”</p><p>“He had this enthusiasm that kind of cracked me up,” Telander said. “He knew all kinds of stuff about Chicago sports. He was deadly serious about this stuff.</p><p>“I realized he had some writing skills. He had a book on Obama, I remember reading that. The enthusiasm affected me. There was a whole lot of optimism. And then he turned that same enthusiasm into writing about sports.”</p><p>That enthusiasm runs through his most recent book, “Why We Root: The Mad Obsessions of a Chicago Sports Fan.” It’s 500 pages of Silverstein’s work as he rides a roller coaster of emotions that began in childhood. He explored not just big events, but their place in our shared culture.</p><p>His current research project is on Paul Patterson, the Bears’ first full-time Black employee. Silverstein said the Bears hired Patterson in 1967 but he wasn’t in the team’s media guide until 1969. He held titles of “player relations” and “traveling secretary” before being lost to history.</p><p>“I love to write, love to research, love to learn and love to figure out a way to tell stories that don’t exist,” Silverstein said.</p><p>Said Telander: “He found something no one’s doing. Doing research, journalism work, interviewing people, being persistent. Other people don’t want to do the work.”<br></p>
entries.author: Jeff Agrest

entries.title: Good Samaritans sprang into action to save baby that fell into Belmont Harbor
entries.summary: <p>Lio Cundiff said he had one thought as he floated in Lake Michigan at Belmont Harbor, balancing a stroller with an 8-month-old girl inside: "I guess if this baby’s going down, then I’m going down with her." </p><p>But his and another Good Samaritan's quick thinking saved the baby's life.</p><p>Cundiff, 30, was wishing his aunt a happy belated birthday when he heard a woman screaming. A gust of wind had just knocked the baby's stroller into the lake around 3 p.m. Wednesday afternoon, in the 3200 block of North DuSable Lake Shore Drive.</p><p>"I just realized that the lady wasn't able to help because she was in too much panic, which is understandable. So I'm like, 'I guess I'm going in,' and I just jumped," Cundiff said. "I had no idea what the plan was.</p><p>"There were a few times where I didn't know if I was gonna stay up long enough," he added. </p><p>Luis Kapost, who lives near the harbor, also jumped into action after seeing what happened. As Cundiff treaded water, Kapost tossed one end of his Chicago Cubs jacket over to him, buying them both time to figure out what to do next.</p><p>"I'm holding one sleeve, he's holding the other, and at least they're not floating away," Kapost, 43, said.</p><p>"Him throwing that jacket down helped me so much," Cundiff said. "I did not know how long I was gonna be able to keep either of us afloat." </p><p>Other passersby who saw the situation called 911 and found a life ring to toss to Cundiff. Kapost and the baby girl's mother helped pull him and the child to safety. </p><p>"It took forever," Kapost said. "It probably happened in the span of five minutes." </p><p>Cundiff, the mother and the child were all hospitalized afterward, officials said. The child was in good condition, according to Chicago police. </p><p>The mother of the child could not be reached directly for comment.</p><p>Cundiff was still at Advocate Illinois Masonic Medical Center for testing Thursday afternoon. He said doctors were "worried about his elevated heart enzymes" and kept him overnight for testing. </p><p>"If all the results turn out OK, and they're not seeing anything, I should be able to leave today," Cundiff said.</p><p>Both Kapost and Cundiff called what happened a "freak accident" and said the mother of the child is not at fault. </p><p>"I hope the mom has grace with herself and doesn't beat herself up too much about it," Cundiff said. "It's not like she wasn't with the baby. ... It's not her fault, and I really hope she knows that." </p><p>Kapost said a blend of his ability to "slow down and think everything through" and Cundiff's impulsively heroic actions made it possible to pull the child out of the water. </p><p>Kapost — who is a pilot for American Airlines — noted his training prepared him for a situation like this. </p><p>"In my line of work, we're taught when you rush, that's when you tend to make mistakes that can eventually lead to disaster," Kapost said. "So that was kind of my focus. Be methodical, take your time, think everything through. </p><p>"If it comes to it, we'll get more people," he added. "It's a small baby. I think everyone in the city would've jumped into the lake if it took us all jumping in there to get her out." </p><p>Kapost applauded Cundiff's actions and hoped he'd get recognized for his efforts. </p><p>"That's the epitome of a hero, someone who's going to act, to help somebody else they don't know even though they're placing their own life in danger," Kapost said. "He's an absolute rock star." </p><p>Cundiff said he felt "weird" about being labeled a hero and he was "just a server and standup comedian in the right place at the right time.</p><p>"Turns out if I have to choose fight or flight, I guess I'm a fighter," Cundiff said. <br> </p>
entries.author: Mohammad Samra

entries.title: From passion to profit: Can the Sky's founding mission survive the league's success?
entries.summary: <p>Tensions are high in the world of women’s basketball.</p><p>WNBA players and owners have been negotiating for more than a year on a new collective-bargaining agreement, and the standoff now threatens to delay the season. In Chicago, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky" target="_blank" >Sky</a> principal owner Michael Alter is <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/01/sky-principal-owner-michael-alter-sued-by-early-minority-investor-over-ownership-stake" >being sued by a minority investor</a> who alleges his stake was unfairly diluted just as the franchise’s value popped.</p><p>Together, the disputes reflect a new era for the Sky and the league, one where millions of dollars are at stake.</p><p>That's a big change. </p><p>For much of the Sky’s history, ownership meant absorbing losses in service of a social mission, not capturing meaningful upside. As recently as 2023, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/18/court-seals-complaint-against-sky-owner-michael-alter-debt-conversion-at-center-of-lawsuit" >the Sky had trouble raising money at an $85 million valuation</a>. Now, one investor estimates the franchise is worth closer to $350 million.</p><p>“It’s all of a sudden real money for people,” that investor told the Sun-Times.</p><p>So what happens when a small community built on belief becomes a booming business?</p><p>The Sun-Times spoke with early investors, fans and players to understand how the meaning of the Sky is changing.</p><p><b>What role should the team's purpose-driven investors play now?</b></p><p>In 2006, Linda Friedman understood that the Sky would be different from an NBA or NFL franchise. Instead of being funded by a single billionaire, it would be backed by a group of mission-driven owners.</p><p></p><p>Alter pitched the investment to her in feminist terms. He asked her to imagine young boys attending games in jerseys bearing women’s names, and how that might shape their understanding of the value women bring to a team.</p><p></p><p>It resonated with Friedman, a lawyer whose life’s work, she says, has been “fighting Wall Street on gender and race.”</p><p></p><p>The mission would be to help create opportunities for players, coaches and fans who otherwise might not have them. Over two decades, she tried to do her part. She bought blocks of tickets and gave them away. She provided pro bono work for the team’s charitable arm.</p><p></p><p>Meanwhile, Alter absorbed the financial losses. Friedman estimates he loaned the team roughly $30 million over the years to keep the team afloat, and has never gotten proper recognition.</p><p>Now, the lawsuit against him bothers her.</p><p>“What kills me about that lawsuit is that instead of saying thank you for hanging in there because now I have something of tremendous value, it’s just all the criticism,” Friedman told the Sun-Times. “It’s not about truth. It’s about money.”</p><p></p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-400000" name="html-embed-module-400000"></a><div class="flourish-embed flourish-scatter" data-src="visualisation/27683354"><script src="https://public.flourish.studio/resources/embed.js"></script><noscript><img src="https://public.flourish.studio/visualisation/27683354/thumbnail" width="100%" alt="scatter visualization" /></noscript></div> </div> </div><p>Friedman said she never expected a financial return from the Sky. The return, for her, was walking into a Sky game and seeing a different crowd than at Wrigley Field or Soldier Field. Not just “privileged kids from the suburbs,” but families and young fans who otherwise might not have experienced professional sports.</p><p>Now she wonders whether that original mission can survive the league’s financial ascent, or whether Wintrust Arena could start to resemble those other venues in a few years.</p><p>“A good part of me would like to have my money back to invest in a similar cause because I think it’s so needed,” she said. “I really enjoyed being a part of this, but to me, the ‘this’ has changed. The need to have purpose-driven, mission-driven people support and build a league has changed. The billionaires want a part. And that’s in the last two years.”</p><p><b>What does the boom feel like to longtime fans?</b></p><p>When the Sky announced they would play their inaugural season at the UIC Pavilion in 2006, Leslie Pilot-Gatton was thrilled. Her daughter was just beginning to fall in love with basketball, and season tickets felt like a way to support that interest.</p><p>On the city’s South Side, organized basketball opportunities for girls were limited. Pilot-Gatton often found herself driving north so her daughter could play.</p><p>“It was really important to have the Sky, for girls to be able to go out and watch women play basketball and have something to look up to,” Pilot-Gatton told the Sun-Times.</p><p>When the team moved to Rosemont’s Allstate Arena from 2010 to 2017, she attended fewer games. But when the Sky returned to the city at Wintrust Arena near McCormick Place, Pilot-Gatton bought season tickets again, this time some of the best seats in the house.</p><p>Her fandom reflects the sense of pride and stewardship many women’s basketball fans feel. She tries — and often succeeds — at getting others hooked. She once brought her trainer, a father of young girls, to a game, and he became a season ticket holder the following season.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-a30000" name="image-a30000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source
