alt="leslie.jpg" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bfc71b8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3118x1750+0+272/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Ff1%2F928d15e24a1bb8bcbe857a6d285f%2Fleslie.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/c025dbf/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3118x1750+0+272/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Ff1%2F928d15e24a1bb8bcbe857a6d285f%2Fleslie.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bfc71b8/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3118x1750+0+272/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F1a%2Ff1%2F928d15e24a1bb8bcbe857a6d285f%2Fleslie.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Leslie Pilot-Gatton (center) converts her personal trainer (Erik Treese, left) and family into a season ticket holder.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Leslie Gatton</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Despite her love for the Bears and White Sox, she calls the Sky “the best game in town” because they play more of a team game. It excites her the way the energy in the stadium has grown as the league’s profile has risen.</p><p>During the 2025 season, the Sky played <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/08/14/from-sellouts-to-the-reese-effect-sky-attendance-tells-a-bigger-story" >two sellout games at the United Center</a> and averaged nearly 10,000. Popularity, however, has come with rising prices: Pilot-Gatton paid $30 per game during the 2021 championship season. Now those same seats cost about $145.</p><p>She worries about what that could mean for the crowd’s makeup. Part of what she loves about the Sky, she said, is that fans come in “all shapes and sizes and ages and colors.” But she plans to renew as long as she can afford it.</p><p>“We don’t want them to leave,” she said. </p><p>She just hopes rising ticket prices will translate into higher salaries and better resources for players — and that those players can become “more a part of the city.”</p><p><b>How has player power changed?</b></p><p>Holding tightly to what you have has long been part of women’s basketball, especially when the WNBA was young and resources were slim.</p><p>In the Sky’s inaugural season in 2006, minimum salaries for players were $30,000. The team practiced at Moody Bible Institute. Their athletic trainer also served as equipment manager and director of basketball operations.</p><p>Still, the circumstances didn’t bother Chelsea Newton, then in her second year in the league.</p><p>“You got to understand: I came from Sacramento in the expansion draft. We just won the championship,” Newton told the Sun-Times. “You’re on cloud nine. Like, this is amazing. I don’t care how much money I get paid.”</p><p>Housing was covered. Cars were paid for. Mostly, they were grateful to have a league to play in.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-730000" name="image-730000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/ca5b75d/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6223e1a/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b36c143/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="img_1_1771442768429.JPG" srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b36c143/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/91848f9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b36c143/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1310x735+0+124/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Ffc%2F43%2F70344a58424385e63cca467e7336%2Fimg-1-1771442768429.JPG" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Chelsea Newton (second from right) and Sky teammates from the 2006 inaugural season.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Chelsea Newton</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The league had barely existed for a decade. Three of the original eight teams folded in the mid-2000s, including the storied Houston Comets. Players felt a sense of precarity.</p><p>Still, Newton pushes back on the notion that women’s basketball has only just burst onto the scene. The year Newton won the championship in Sacramento, the team drew as many fans as Angel Reese’s rookie season with the Sky.</p><p>Waves of interest and pockets of support for women’s basketball have existed for decades.</p><p>In the modern era, though, television exposure and social media have propelled player profiles. In 2021, the NCAA changed the rules to allow players to profit off their name, image and likeness. That led to endorsement deals and accelerating visibility for stars. </p><p>Reese now has more than 5 million followers on Instagram, and the 2023 national championship game between LSU and Iowa drew almost 10 million viewers.</p><p>Those numbers validated something that Friedman and other early Sky investors admit they didn’t see coming: women’s basketball has tremendous market potential. WNBA franchise valuations have soared in anticipation of further growth.</p><p>Players are no longer “just grateful” to have a league. During collective-bargaining negotiations, they have rejected proposals that include salaries topping $1 million, pushed for a revenue-sharing model closer to major men’s leagues, and authorized a strike if necessary.</p><p>“I love the fact that the players stand up for themselves,” Newton said. “I love the fact that these are the talks.”</p><p>Newton is close with many current WNBA players, including the Sky’s 2021 Finals MVP Kahleah Copper, who she coached at Rutgers. She lived the league’s fragile beginnings and now mentors the NIL generation as an associate head coach at Texas A&M.</p><p>That dual perspective informs her view of the moment.</p><p>“I just want it to work out for both sides and to make sure that the players get what they need and the league survives and continues to grow,” she said.</p><p><b>How should the WNBA deal with resource disparities?</b></p><p>When money floods into a space, it rarely distributes evenly. Newton is living the disparities NIL has created in the college game, as programs without deep pockets struggle to keep up.</p><p>The same dynamics apply in the WNBA. Some teams have built gleaming practice facilities and robust medical and performance staff. Other teams are still playing in tiny arenas and practicing in shared spaces.</p><p>That’s why players are fighting for minimum standards in the next CBA. Discussing the latest round of negotiations on her podcast, Liberty star Breanna Stewart said players are demanding that every team provide resources that support performance, including chefs, massage therapists and dedicated practice facilities.</p><p>Stewart even suggested that owners who can’t meet the new standard should consider selling.</p><p>From a current player’s perspective, it's tempting to boot the stragglers and invite in the billionaires. But history is a cautionary tale.</p><p>As Newton’s experience in Sacramento showed, an owner’s willingness to endure the lulls matters as much as investment during boom times. The Monarchs’ owner abruptly folded the team in 2009 after attendance dipped, shifting his focus to the NBA’s Sacramento Kings.</p><p>Even as the league booms, long-term commitment should count for something.</p><p>The Sky score highly on the commitment-o-meter: Alter and company are the longest-tenured independent (non-NBA affiliated) owners in the league.</p><p>It’s the willingness-to-adapt category where the Sky are unproven.</p><p>They’ve taken steps to modernize the team, with <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/06/skys-new-practice-facility-will-be-ready-by-late-spring-ceo-adam-fox-says" >a new practice facility coming in Bedford Park</a>. But a resistance to change lingers. They were the last team in the league to separate the coach and general manager roles, and as of the 2025 season, the team’s strength and conditioning coach was still organizing travel logistics.</p><p>Alter has choices to make. In a league reshaped by money and modern expectations, the Sky’s mission may need reimagining.</p>
entries.author: Alissa Hirsh

entries.title: Venezuela produce entre los mejores músicos clásicos del mundo. Su futuro artístico es incierto
entries.summary: <p>El Millennium Park no fue un desafío para Pacho Flores.</p><p>La mayoría miraría el mar de personas en el Pritzker Pavilion y se desanimaría. No el trompetista de 44 años nacido en Venezuela. Durante un concierto con el Festival de Música de Grant Park el pasado mes de junio, su sonido brillante y su virtuosa agilidad danzaron sobre el pegajoso calor del verano.</p><p>En un momento de un solo, apuntó la campana de su trompeta hacia el director —el director artístico del Festival de Música de Grant Park, Giancarlo Guerrero, un viejo amigo— y sopló un provocador sonido.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-d00000" name="module-d00000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Antes de que Flores se convirtiera en un solista internacional y Guerrero alcanzara la fama suficiente para hacer <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2026/02/09/bad-bunny-elige-a-director-de-chicago-para-liderar-la-orquesta-del-show-de-medio-tiempo-del-super-bowl" target="_blank" >una aparición especial</a> en el vibrante espectáculo de medio tiempo panlatino de Bad Bunny, ambos hombres pasaron por la misma organización: el Sistema Nacional de Orquestas y Coros Juveniles e Infantiles de Venezuela, o “El Sistema” para abreviar.</p><p>Flores fue el trompetista principal de la Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar, una orquesta de estrellas que acepta a la <i>crème de la crème</i> de las orquestas regionales del Sistema en toda Venezuela. Guerrero, entonces en sus 20 años, fue nombrado para dirigir una de esas orquestas, en el estado occidental de Táchira, su primer trabajo profesional como director.</p><p>“Básicamente le debo mi carrera a El Sistema y Venezuela”, dijo Guerrero, de 56 años, a WBEZ en una reciente entrevista telefónica.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Antes de que Pacho Flores (izquierda) se convirtiera en un solista internacional y Giancarlo Guerrero (derecha) alcanzara la fama suficiente para tener una aparición especial en el show de medio tiempo de Bad Bunny, ambos hombres pasaron por la misma organización: el Sistema Nacional de Orquestas y Coros Juveniles e Infantiles de Venezuela.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Courtesy of Grant Park Music Festival</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>El Sistema fue fundado en 1975 por el economista y director José Antonio Abreu, un exministro de cultura que utilizó su influencia política para convertir a El Sistema en un programa dirigido por el estado. El auge petrolero del país alimentó el rápido crecimiento de El Sistema, organizado en los llamados <i>núcleos</i> —como el que dirigía Guerrero en Táchira— a lo largo de los 23 estados de Venezuela.</p><p>Su orquesta principal, la Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar se convirtió en una sensación global después de <a class="Link" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8wS-1Eqonk" target="_blank" >una actuación explosiva en los BBC Proms de 2007</a>, vistiendo rompevientos con la bandera venezolana. Más recientemente, la orquesta abrió para Coldplay durante sus 10 conciertos agotados en el Wembley Stadium el verano pasado, con el vocalista Chris Martin <a class="Link" href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GW29-Tgwcz4&list=RDGW29-Tgwcz4&start_radio=1" target="_blank" >elogiándola en el escenario</a> como “quizás la mejor orquesta del mundo”.</p><p>Ahora, los exalumnos de El Sistema están notoriamente bien representados en instituciones de música clásica y conservatorios en todas partes. Este otoño, el director de orquesta nacido en Venezuela, Gustavo Dudamel, de 45 años, asumirá las riendas del puesto de música clásica más visible de América, la Filarmónica de Nueva York, mientras sigue actuando como director musical de la Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar. Su colega director Rafael Payare, quien participó en El Sistema al mismo tiempo que Dudamel, dirige las sinfonías de San Diego y Montreal.</p><p>Y los músicos venezolanos son miembros de algunas de las mejores orquestas del mundo, desde la Filarmónica de Berlín hasta nuestra propia Sinfónica de Chicago (CSO).</p><p>“Las personas hablan de petróleo, especialmente hoy en día en Venezuela”, contó Guerrero. “Honestamente, es la música clásica profesional la que puede ser la exportación más grande de ese país”.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>“Debo básicamente mi carrera a El Sistema y Venezuela”, dijo Giancarlo Guerrero, director artístico y director principal del Festival de Música de Grant Park de Chicago, en una reciente entrevista telefónica con WBEZ.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Victor Hilitski for the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>En medio de un punto álgido en las relaciones entre Estados Unidos y Venezuela y el aumento de la aplicación de la ley de inmigración doméstica, el futuro de esa exportación nunca ha estado tan en cuestión. El pasado mes de junio, el Departamento de Estado <a class="Link" href="https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/News/visas-news/suspension-of-visa-issuance-to-foreign-nationals-to-protect-the-united-states-from-foreign-terrorists-and-other-national-security-and-public-safety-threats.html" target="_blank" >detuvo la emisión de visas</a>, incluidas las visas estudiantiles, a ciudadanos venezolanos, con limitadas excepciones. Esas excepciones se redujeron aún más <a class="Link" href="https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/News/visas-news/suspension-of-visa-issuance-to-foreign-nationals-to-protect-the-security-of-the-united-states.html" target="_blank" >en enero</a>.</p><p>Esto significa incertidumbre para los músicos venezolanos que de otro modo podrían haberse trasladado a Chicago para perseguir su carrera, ya sea en los muchos conservatorios de primer nivel de la ciudad o a través de oportunidades profesionales tempranas en la Sinfónica de Chicago, la Orquesta Cívica de Chicago o el Festival de Música de Grant Park.</p><p>“Tengo dos [estudiantes venezolanos] que quieren venir, que son realmente buenos, y me gustaría que vinieran”, dijo Almita Vamos, una pedagoga de violín radicada en Chicago cuyo prestigioso estudio atrae a estudiantes de todo el mundo. “No sé si puedan”.</p><h3><b>Jugar, cantar y luchar </b></h3><p>El Sistema es una organización masiva que desafía una fácil definición. Sus operaciones centrales se relacionan con su red nacional de escuelas de música comunitarias que ofrecen instrucción extracurricular a niños de forma gratuita.</p><p>Sin embargo, también abarca varios conjuntos profesionales, todos en la cúspide de sus respectivos núcleos. Los estudiantes destacados, sin importar cuán jóvenes sean, pueden progresar y unirse a las filas.</p><p>El nicaragüense Guerrero, criado en Costa Rica, señala que niños tan jóvenes como de 12 y 13 años tocaban junto a músicos veteranos en su orquesta profesional en Táchira. A veces, miembros de diversos niveles del núcleo tocan juntos para eventos especiales, un espectáculo de rendimiento orquestal que también sirve como experiencia de aprendizaje para los músicos más jóvenes.</p><p>“Estábamos haciendo sinfonías de Beethoven con 400 músicos”, recordó Guerrero.</p><p>Incluso en sus primeros años, el enfoque de El Sistema en la educación en conjunto —al principio en la educación orquestal, con coros añadidos más tarde— lo distinguió de otros programas de música gratuitos. El fundador José Antonio Abreu codificó la misión de El Sistema como una de elevación social, trazando paralelismos entre la naturaleza colaborativa de un conjunto musical y la participación cívica. Más idealísticamente, El Sistema se posiciona como una forma para que Venezuela conquiste la creciente pobreza y la violencia de pandillas —reflejado en su mantra de “jugar, cantar y luchar”.</p><p>“Se veía al proyecto siempre como desarrollo nacional en lugar de desarrollo cultural o artístico”, dice Norma Núñez-Ruch, gerente de operaciones del lugar del Loop <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/music/2024/10/17/guarneri-hall-performances-chicago-classical-music-venue" target="_blank" >Guarneri Hall</a> y del Centro Cultural Segundo Ruiz Belvis en el vecindario de Hermosa.</p><p>Núñez-Ruch, de 39 años, se formó en la viola a través de El Sistema y ocupó puestos administrativos en el programa durante seis años antes de trabajar en algunos programas de derivación en Estados Unidos.</p><p>Después de que la Orquesta Simón Bolívar, y por extensión El Sistema, deslumbrara al mundo hace 20 años, surgieron programas imitadores en comunidades con pocos recursos en todo el mundo. Algunos de los ejemplos más prominentes en Estados Unidos incluyen la Orquesta Juvenil de Los Ángeles (YOLA) de la Filarmónica de Los Ángeles y el programa OrchKids de la Sinfonía de Baltimore, una creación del director principal de Ravinia, Marin Alsop.</p><p>A nivel local, la programación Reach Teach Play de Ravinia también incluye un <a class="Link" href="https://chicagophilharmonic.org/national-seminario-ravinia-recap/" target="_blank" >pilar inspirado en el Sistema para estudiantes orquestales</a>, al igual que <a class="Link" href="https://peoplesmusicschool.org/50years/" target="_blank" >la Escuela de Música del Pueblo</a> en el vecindario de Uptown.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div Crown dentro de The Audrey, ubicado en el lado noroeste de los terrenos del Festival Ravinia, el jueves 7 de agosto de 2025, en Highland Park, Illinois." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/24d53a1/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5c%2F3f%2F2b8082114ac38a42ddec513f88e2%2Fraviniareno-080925-9.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/a223b1b/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5c%2F3f%2F2b8082114ac38a42ddec513f88e2%2Fraviniareno-080925-9.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/24d53a1/2147483647/strip/true/crop/3000x1684+0+158/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F5c%2F3f%2F2b8082114ac38a42ddec513f88e2%2Fraviniareno-080925-9.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>El programa Reach Teach Play de Ravinia incluye un pilar inspirado en el Sistema para estudiantes de orquesta.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Tyler Pasciak LaRiviere/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>El Sistema no es meramente un programa pedagógico. Músicos de cualquier edad pueden avanzar hacia sus orquestas profesionales remuneradas y, en muchos casos, los niños son pagados lo suficiente como para convertirse en los principales sostenedores de su familia. Esto incentiva la participación y progresión de los estudiantes en El Sistema, pero también a veces le confiere un brutal sentido de competencia.</p><p>“Tengo un amigo muy cercano que me dijo que ganaba más dinero a los 20 que su padre, que era ingeniero”, dice Ricardo Lorenz, un compositor nacido en Venezuela que ahora enseña en la Universidad Estatal de Michigan.</p><p>Lorenz y Núñez-Ruch recuerdan ambos una época en la que esos salarios eran suficientes para mantener a los músicos dentro de Venezuela. Pero cuando su economía colapsó en la década de 2010, incluso El Sistema, que estaba bien financiado, ya no tenía fondos para retener a los músicos. Un aumento en la elección de músicos por estudiar y trabajar en el extranjero siguió, y la pérdida de Venezuela se convirtió en la ganancia del mundo.</p><h3><b>Donde la música y la política chocan </b></h3><p>El Sistema y el propio Abreu han sido objeto de críticas generalizadas tanto dentro como fuera de Venezuela durante años.</p><p>El programa fue fundado más de 20 años antes de la presidencia de Hugo Chávez, cuya ideología populista sentó las bases para el autoritarismo más austero de su sucesor, Nicolás Maduro. Pero el grado en que El Sistema ha sido utilizado como una herramienta de propaganda por ambos regímenes ha llevado a acusaciones de oportunismo político y “artwashing”, en otras palabras, usar la cultura para distraer de una sombría realidad política.</p><p>La pianista venezolana Gabriela Montero, que actúa regularmente con orquestas de clase mundial como la Sinfónica de Chicago, es una de esos críticos. Ella dijo al Times de Londres el año pasado que “ya no es moralmente aceptable albergar orquestas de propiedad y operadas por estados forajidos como mecanismos de poder e influencia suave”.</p><p>Muchos han instado a Dudamel a tomar una postura firme similar. Aunque el director <a class="Link" href="https://www.npr.org/sections/deceptivecadence/2017/05/04/526897569/gustavo-dudamel-addresses-venezuelas-leaders-enough-is-enough" target="_blank" >ha criticado al régimen de Maduro en el pasado</a> —más notablemente en 2017, cuando un estudiante de El Sistema fue asesinado por soldados durante una protesta— sigue siendo el director musical de la Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar, el conjunto más prestigioso de El Sistema, y un defensor de la organización en general.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-711533" name="image-711533"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Los músicos venezolanos son miembros de algunas de las mejores orquestas del mundo, desde la Filarmónica de Berlín hasta nuestra propia Sinfónica de Chicago.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Ashlee Rezin/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Cuando trabajó para El Sistema durante los años de Chávez, Núñez-Ruch señala que muchos dentro de la organización eran claros sobre las realidades políticas de Venezuela. Al mismo tiempo, El Sistema recibe aproximadamente el 80% de su financiación del gobierno venezolano, dejando a la organización esencialmente atrapada.</p><p>“En mi percepción, [la actitud de El Sistema] era, ‘Di lo que quieras decir siempre y cuando podamos sostener el trabajo’. Esa es parte de la estrategia política de la organización y su liderazgo”, asegura Núñez-Ruch.</p><p>La disfunción del gobierno venezolano y sus tendencias de fuerza a veces se traducen en El Sistema mismo. Mientras vivía en Chicago a principios de 2000, Lorenz estaba ayudando a liderar un programa comunitario con la Sinfónica de Chicago en Pilsen. Abreu instó a Lorenz a forjar una conexión entre la CSO y El Sistema, que nunca se concretó.</p><p>Pero Abreu, que siempre fue “solidario” con la carrera de Lorenz, más tarde se comunicó preguntando si Lorenz estaría interesado en regresar a Venezuela. Mientras Lorenz consideraba la oferta, Chávez nombró al compositor para reemplazar al actual presidente del Instituto Universitario de Estudios Musicales de Caracas a través de su programa de televisión semanal, “Aló Presidente”. Lorenz se sorprendió. Solo había estado en conversaciones preliminares para el puesto, que rápidamente declinó. El episodio efectivamente puso fin a su relación con Abreu. “Él estaba muy decepcionado después de eso”, recuerda Lorenz. (Abreu falleció en 2018).</p><p>Más recientemente, el académico británico Geoffrey Baker ha sembrado dudas sobre la idea de que el programa prioriza la elevación social. En ausencia de datos demográficos, que El Sistema mantiene en privado, su libro de 2014, “El Sistema: Orchestrating Venezuela's Youth”, se basó en cientos de entrevistas y un año observando los núcleos de El Sistema.</p><p>Los hallazgos de Baker indicaron que el programa atendía a un núcleo demográfico de niños de clases media-alta, con estudiantes pobres en minoría.</p><p>Además, Baker observó que la filosofía educativa “revolucionaria” de El Sistema era, si acaso, retrógrada. Los núcleos más a menudo parecían viejas escuelas europeas donde las horas interminables de práctica eran la norma.</p><p>“Pensé ingenuamente que cuando Abreu muriera y más músicos abandonaran el país, algunos comenzarían a hablar sobre los problemas”, escribió Baker a WBEZ por correo electrónico. “Pero no conté con el hecho de que el buen nombre de El Sistema era esencial para sus perspectivas laborales en el extranjero, era su boleto de comida”.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-3d0ae6" name="image-3d0ae6"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" involucrando a ICE, como parte de un día nacional de acción, el sábado 10 de enero de 2026." srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bad3ba9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/e0fe5f0/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bad3ba9/2147483647/strip/true/crop/2500x1403+0+132/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2Fc7%2Fde%2Fb722f4614163949410d8b02d0d2e%2Ficeprotest-260111-028.jpg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Los manifestantes se reúnen en Water Tower Park, en el centro de Chicago, en enero de 2026 para denunciar el arresto del presidente de Venezuela, Maduro. El año crítico en las relaciones entre Estados Unidos y Venezuela ha interrumpido un flujo de músicos desde el país hacia programas orquestales en todo el mundo.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Núñez-Ruch no disputa los relatos de política interna y ensayos interminables. Pero siente que El Sistema operaba con más agilidad política de lo que a menudo se le da crédito. Ella señala el uso de simbolismo venezolano en las giras de El Sistema en lugar del logo del Partido Socialista Unido, en un momento en que esa imagen era omnipresente dentro de Venezuela.</p><p>“Gestionar eso no es una hazaña pequeña”, dijo Núñez-Ruch sobre la capacidad de la organización para separarse de la iconografía relacionada con Chávez. “Es algo que es muy heroico, y solo en retrospectiva, y fuera del país, puedo ver lo magistral que fue no cruzar esa línea”.</p><p>Lorenz también “debe una deuda de gratitud” a El Sistema, escribió por correo electrónico, a pesar de sus propios sentimientos encontrados. El próximo mes, Dudamel dirigirá una <a class="Link" href="https://www.laphil.com/musicdb/pieces/7415/humboldts-nature" target="_blank" >nueva obra</a> de Lorenz para conmemorar su última temporada con la Filarmónica de Los Ángeles, que ha liderado desde 2009. La pieza está inspirada en el paisaje de Venezuela: la escarpada costa oriental, los pájaros gorjeando en la Cueva del Guácharo de seis millas de largo y los tambores resonando sobre el Lago Tacarigua, al norte.</p><p>“La parte triste de todas estas cosas que han sucedido en el último mes es que están tratando de llevarnos 100 años atrás, donde lo único que tiene Venezuela es el petróleo”, dice Lorenz. “Pensé que habíamos superado eso”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
entries.author: Hannah Edgar | WBEZ

entries.title: Police: Residents rescued from armed intruder in Arlington Heights
entries.summary: <p>Police responding to a reported burglary in progress at an Arlington Heights home Thursday morning rescued a family from an armed intruder, authorities said.</p><p>Hours later, a large police presence remains on the scene in the 800 block of North Chestnut Avenue amid a standoff with the suspected perpetrator.</p><p>The events began shortly after 7:33 a.m. when police officers called to the single-family residence determined a suspected armed offender was inside with two homeowners, officials said.</p><p>The residents were able to secure themselves inside a bedroom and call 911, according to Arlington Heights police.</p><p>Officers burst into the home, located the residents and led them outside to safety, police said. During the rescue, officers reported hearing a gunshot inside the home, authorities said.</p><p>For more on this story, please visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.dailyherald.com/20260219/news/mayor-police-surround-dangerous-person-inside-arlington-heights-house/" target="_blank" >DailyHerald.com</a>.<br></p>
entries.author: Daily Herald

entries.title: Caitlin Tracey's husband pleads not guilty to new charges in her death
entries.summary: <p>The husband of Caitlin Tracey, who is accused of pushing her off a 24-story stairwell at a South Loop condo building in 2024, was in court Thursday facing additional charges in connection with her death.</p><p>Adam Beckerink 47, was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2026/01/16/caitlin-tracey-adam-beckerink-crime-south-loop" target="_blank" ><u>charged with first-degree murder</u></a> in Tracey’s death last month.</p><p>During the brief hearing at the Leighton Criminal Court Building before Cook County Judge Joanne Rosado, Beckerink pleaded not guilty to new charges of concealment of homicidal death, making a false report to 911, and making a false report to a public safety agency as well as murder. </p><p>Beckerink, whose wrists were shackled, was wearing a short-sleeved orange jumpsuit and did not appear show any emotion. Tracey’s parents were in attendance.</p><p>Tracey, 36, was found dead Oct. 27 at the bottom of a stairwell in a South Loop high-rise after residents of the building found a severed foot in the stairwell. Prosecutors said Beckerink, a Chicago lawyer, pushed Tracey off of a 24th floor railing of their building in the 1200 block of South Prairie Avenue.</p><p>Tracey had been in a relationship with Beckerink since 2022. They lived together at the South Loop condo, but Tracey also owned a home in New Buffalo, Michigan.</p><p>Tracey obtained an order of protection against Beckerink in Cook County in 2023 after multiple domestic battery reports to Chicago police, but later dropped it after he threatened to sue her for defamation.</p><p>Prosecutors said Tracey had disclosed to a court-appointed victim advocate that Beckerink had previously threatened to throw her over a flight of stairs.</p><p>He served a 93-day sentence last year in the Berrien County jail in Michigan for domestic abuse against Tracey. He was arrested by Chicago police officers and U.S. Marshals Great Lakes Regional Fugitive Task Force after he was released on Jan. 12.</p><p>Shortly before 11:30 p.m. Oct. 25, 2024, four residents in the South Loop high-rise reported hearing an “unusually loud noise” that sounded like something striking metal from inside the building’s stairwell, prosecutors said.</p><p>Around 3 a.m. the next morning, surveillance camera footage showed Beckerink hauling a luggage cart filled with jackets and bags from the building’s parking garage.</p><p>Later that day, Beckerink told the building’s concierge, whom he had befriended while living there, that Tracey had been missing since 10 p.m. the day before.</p><p>Beckerink later filed a missing person report with Chicago police, telling officers that Tracey had left their home around 9 or 10 p.m. the night before to go for a run and didn’t bring her phone or keys with her. He also told officers that he had been in Michigan and hadn’t seen Tracey in more than a month, according to prosecutors. However, detectives found building surveillance video showing the two together on Oct. 24, according to a Chicago police report.</p><p>Surveillance footage from the condo didn’t show Tracey leaving the building around the time that Beckerink had reported, prosecutors said.</p><p>A day after Tracey’s body was found, Beckerink was arrested and accused of filing a false police report. He was later released without charges being filed.</p><p>After Tracey’s death, her parents and Beckerink fought over the custody of her remains. A Michigan judge eventually granted custody to Tracey’s parents, and a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2024/11/15/caitlin-tracey-adam-beckerink-south-loop-high-rise-stairwell" target="_blank" >Cook County judge</a> later accepted that ruling.</p><p>Beckerink is due back in court on March 18.<br></p>
entries.author: Cindy Hernandez

entries.title: What to know about the March 17 primary for the Cook County Board of Review
entries.summary: <p></p><h3>What does the Cook County Board of Review do?</h3><p>The Board of Review holds huge power; it decides on appeals of property tax assessments across the county, which includes about 2 million parcels. </p><p>The Board of Review commissioners can effectively cut tax bills for individual homeowners, and in 2024, the agency <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/bears-stadium/2024/11/25/bears-stadium-arlington-heights-lakefront-michael-reese-soldier-field" target="_blank" ><u>effectively ruled on the taxes</u></a> that the Chicago Bears should have to pay for Arlington Park, where the football team has hoped to build a new stadium.</p><p>The board also has played a role in the dispute over <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2020/2/7/21126855/donald-trump-tower-chicago-property-tax-appeal-investigation" target="_blank" ><u>the tax bill</u></a> for President Donald Trump’s downtown Chicago skyscraper.</p><h3>Why is Cook County Board of Review commissioner a powerful position?</h3><p>There are just three commissioners on the Board of Review, each representing part of the county. A majority can decide whether to change the initial valuation set by the county assessor. </p><p>The current assessor, Fritz Kaegi, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/other-views/2025/12/15/cook-county-board-of-review-blame-home-property-tax-increase-fritz-kaegi-assessor" target="_blank" ><u>recently criticized</u></a> the Board of Review, alleging that the commissioners have favored business interests over homeowners, who’ve been hit with rising tax bills. But the Board of Review has <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/letters-to-the-editor/2025/12/29/cook-county-assessor-board-review-samantha-steele-fritz-kaegi-assisted-suicide-cta-safety" target="_blank" ><u>fired back</u></a> at Kaegi.</p><p>All three commissioners are Democrats. But two of them, Larry Rogers and George Cardenas, often have clashed with the third member of the panel, Samantha Steele.</p><h3>Who are the incumbents, George Cardenas and Samantha Steele?</h3><p>Cardenas is a former Chicago City Council member and one of two commissioners up for re-election this year. Cardenas has the support of the county’s Democratic organization.</p><p>Steele is seeking a second term after a tumultuous first four years on the Board of Review. She is a former assessor in Tippecanoe County, Indiana, who was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2024/11/23/cook-county-politician-board-of-review-samantha-steele-chicago-police" target="_blank" ><u>arrested and charged</u></a> with drunk driving on the North Side of Chicago in 2024. The case is pending.</p><p>The county paid a <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/cook-county/2025/01/15/a-former-cook-county-agency-employee-will-get-180-000-in-a-legal-settlement" target="_blank" ><u>$180,000 settlement</u></a> last year to a former Steele aide who sued in federal court, alleging he faced retaliation as a whistleblower.</p><h3>Who are their challengers, Juanita Irizarry and Liz Nicholson?</h3><p>Irizarry, who is vying to unseat Cardenas, is a longtime activist in the Puerto Rican neighborhoods of Chicago. She is best known for successfully <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/city-hall/2023/12/5/23989834/juanita-irizarry-leaving-friends-of-the-parks-executive-director-lakefront-lucas-museum" target="_blank" ><u>leading environmentalist opposition</u></a> to plans to build a Lucas Museum of Narrative Art on the lakefront as the head of the Friends of the Parks group.</p><p>Liz Nicholson, Steele’s challenger, was a longtime campaign operative for Illinois Democrats. She was a top adviser for three decades to former state Senate President John Cullerton.</p><p>Irizary and Nicholson are enjoying heavy support from many elected officials, including members of Congress.</p>
entries.author: Dan Mihalopoulos | WBEZ

entries.title: Schakowsky withdraws Donna Miller endorsement in 2nd Congressional District over AIPAC support
entries.summary: <p>U.S. Rep. Jan Schakowsky has withdrawn her endorsement of Cook County Commissioner Donna Miller in the 2nd Congressional District race over Miller receiving campaign funding from American Israel Public Affairs Committee donors — and an AIPAC super PAC that is running TV ads to support her.</p><p>Schakowsky endorsed Miller on Jan. 29 — with the congresswoman saying Miller "has spent her career fighting for families, veterans, seniors and working people throughout Cook County." But Schakowsky earlier this month decided to pull that endorsement amid a flurry of media reports and accounts from 2nd Congressional District candidates of Miller receiving money from AIPAC donors and an AIPAC-affiliated super PAC running ads benefiting her.</p><p>Schakowsky first confirmed the withdrawal of her endorsement to the Chicago Sun-Times Thursday.</p><p>"Illinois deserves leaders who put voters first, not AIPAC or out-of-state Trump donors," Schakowsky said in a statement to the Sun-Times. "I cannot support any candidate running for Congress who is funded by these outside interests. That is one of the many reasons I am supporting Daniel Biss in IL-09. Daniel will always put Illinois families ahead of outside influence." </p><p>Schakowsky made the Miller endorsement before she was aware of outside money coming into the race, including from donors supportive of President Donald Trump. </p><p>At a forum in Thornton Township Saturday, Miller was asked about Schakowsky's endorsement but declined to provide details. </p><p>"I've been friends with Jan Schakowksy for over 20 years," Miller said. </p><p>A super PAC called Affordable Chicago Now has spent $868,000 to help Miller in TV ads that highlight her work for Planned Parenthood of Illinois. Miller has also reported more than $875,000 in contributions from donors who have given to AIPAC, the powerful pro-Israel organization, or its affiliated super PAC, the United Democracy Project. The super PAC has received millions of dollars from AIPAC and has spent heavily in Democratic primaries. The super PACS are not allowed to directly coordinate with campaigns. </p><p>AIPAC is playing a role in four congressional races in Illinois — helping to boost Miller in the 2nd; former U.S. Rep. Melissa Bean in the 8th; state Sen. Laura Fine in the 9th; and Chicago City Treasurer Melissa Conyears Ervin in the 7th. United Democracy Project has spent more than $753,000 to support Conyears Ervin. </p><p>Asked about AIPAC support earlier this month by the Sun-Times, Miller denied she was getting dollars from "MAGA donors."</p><p>“I don't have any MAGA donors. People are contributing to my campaign because I have a strong record. My message is resonating. This is what I'm talking about out in the field,” Miller said. “And who's talking about these other issues? I haven't heard anyone talk about it until my opponents realize that they're losing and they want to attack me.”</p><p>Asked if she supported “unconditional military aid for Israel,” Miller said, “Israel does have a right to exist.”</p><p>“I also come from a military family, so I understand the impact that the military has when we're talking about securing our democracy,” Miller said. “So I do feel that we need to make sure that we have a strong Middle East.”</p><p>Miller's campaign removed Schakowsky's endorsement on its website and on Facebook. But it remained live on its Instagram page.</p><p>Miller is leading fundraising in the crowded field to replace outgoing Rep. Robin Kelly, as former U.S. Rep. Jesse Jackson Jr. vies for his old seat. State Sen. Robert Peters, D-Chicago, has the progressive backing, including a glowing endorsement from U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders. Rounding out the field are state Sen. Willie Preston; Metropolitan Water Reclamation District Board member Yumeka Brown; Adal Regis, who worked in Kelly’s district office; management consultant Eric France; attorney Patrick “PJK” Keating; Toni C. Brown and Sidney Moore.</p><p>Schakowsky in January <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/elections/2026/01/07/jan-schakowsky-endorsement-evanston-mayor-daniel-biss-successor-kat-abughazaleh-9th-district" target="_blank" >endorsed Biss</a> to replace her in the 9th Congressional District. The longtime Democratic congresswoman also pointedly said that she didn’t want “out-of-state donors and special interests to buy this seat.”</p><p>Elect Chicago Women is spending on TV ads benefiting Fine, one of Biss' challengers. Biss and others say the super PAC is working to benefit AIPAC. Fine has also raised more than $1.2 million in the last reporting period, with about $1 million coming from donors who have given to AIPAC-affiliated groups. </p><p>Asked about AIPAC donors by the Sun-Times earlier this month, Fine said: "Anybody who's supporting me is supporting my record, supporting a record of getting things changed when it comes to health care, standing up to corporate polluters, making sure Illinois is a 100% pro choice state."</p><p>A total of 15 Democratic candidates are running for the 9th Congressional District seat in the primary, including progressive content creator Kat Abughazaleh, Phil Andrew, Bushra Amiwala, state Sen. Mike Simmons, economist Jeff Cohen, state Rep. Hoan Huynh, former federal prosecutor Nick Pyati, veteran Sam Polan, civil rights attorney Howard Rosenblum, Evanston resident Bethany Johnson, union organizer Justin Ford, Patricia A. Brown and Mark Arnold Fredrickson.</p>
entries.author: Tina Sfondeles

entries.title: Líderes religiosos entran en la instalación de ICE de Broadview en Miércoles de Ceniza tras orden judicial
entries.summary: <p>Con ceniza en la frente y las manos entrelazadas, tres miembros del clero oraron antes de caminar hacia el centro del Servicio Inmigración y Control de Aduanas (ICE) de Broadview, luego de meses de haber sido denegado su acceso.</p><p>Líderes de fe activos en la oposición a las prácticas de inmigración de la administración de Trump ingresaron a la instalación el Miércoles de Ceniza por primera vez en meses, después de que un juez federal en Chicago emitiera una orden de mandato preliminar la semana pasada, ordenando al Departamento de Seguridad Nacional (DHS) permitirles entrar al edificio.</p><p>“No dirás que se siente bien porque no se siente bien tener que hacer esto”, dijo el padre Paul Keller, Provincial de los Misioneros Claretianos. “Pero estamos agradecidos por la oportunidad de brindar presencia y cuidado pastoral a las personas que se encuentran en circunstancias muy traumáticas en sus vidas”.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-810000" name="module-810000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>DHS dijo anteriormente que los líderes de fe no podían ingresar al edificio porque era un centro de procesamiento, no una instalación de detención.</p><p>Sin embargo, durante las detenciones de inmigración intensificadas en el área de Chicago durante el Operativo Midway Blitz el otoño pasado, el centro de procesamiento <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/10/01/broadview-immigration-processing-center-detention-ice-dhs" target="_blank" >operó como un centro de detención de facto</a> pero carecía de las reglas y supervisión necesarias, según reveló una investigación del Sun-Times y WBEZ.</p><p>Cuatro inmigrantes y tres miembros del personal en la instalación recibieron la comunión y ceniza en la frente para los servicios del Miércoles de Ceniza, marcando uno de los momentos más sagrados del año para los cristianos y católicos. Los cuatro migrantes parecían haber sido detenidos recientemente, dijeron los miembros del clero.</p><p>“Vimos ojos llorosos, confusión, incertidumbre”, contó el padre Leandro Fossá, pastor de Nuestra Señora del Monte Carmelo en Melrose Park. “También se podía ver que estaban receptivos, así que sintieron la esperanza del momento al ver que la iglesia estaba allí con ellos”.</p><p>Lo que los miembros del clero encontraron dentro de la instalación era un contraste absoluto con lo que habría sido el año pasado durante el operativo de inmigración de la administración de Trump. Las ventanas aún estaban tapiadas y una cerca y otras barreras mantenían a los manifestantes y al público a raya, pero el edificio estaba vacío cuando llegaron, dijeron. Sólo cuatro detenidos llegaron mientras ellos estaban allí, una diferencia notable con los informes del otoño pasado sobre el edificio abarrotado de personas y con poco espacio para dormir.</p><p>Los defensores religiosos de los inmigrantes, incluidas las hermanas fallecidas Pat Murphy y JoAnn Persch, solían visitar regularmente a los inmigrantes detenidos en la instalación de Broadview hasta que la pandemia de COVID-19 llevó las visitas a un formato en línea en 2020.</p><p>Pero después de que se les <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz/2025/11/04/nuevamente-rechazan-peticion-para-darles-la-comunion-a-detenidos-en-broadview" target="_blank" >negara el acceso</a> este otoño mientras la administración de Trump intensificaba su aplicación de inmigración en el área, algunos miembros del clero <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/immigration/2025/11/19/clergy-sue-ice-over-restriction-on-providing-religious-services-to-detainees-intimidation-of-religious" target="_blank" >demandaron al gobierno federal</a>. La Coalición por el Liderazgo Espiritual y Público, un demandante en el caso, acusó al gobierno de violar la ley federal y los derechos de la Primera Enmienda de los líderes religiosos y los detenidos.</p><p>“Queremos continuar haciendo lo que hemos podido hacer durante tantos años y que de repente se detuvo con el cambio de dirección”, dijo la hermana Jeremy Midura, una hermana feliciana y una de las demandantes en el juicio. “La hermana Pat y la hermana JoAnn podían entrar en la instalación. Todo eso cambió”.</p><p>Los miembros del clero dijeron que la instalación parecía limpia, a pesar de los informes sobre condiciones de hacinamiento dentro del edificio el otoño pasado, y que los agentes de inmigración fueron serviciales. Dijeron que tienen la intención de programar más visitas a la instalación.</p><h3>El cardenal Cupich elogia la injunction que permitió la entrada del clero a la instalación de ICE</h3><p>El cardenal Blase Cupich, arzobispo de Chicago, elogió la injunction del juez federal que permitió la entrada del clero en la instalación de ICE. En un comunicado, dijo, “La libertad religiosa es una piedra angular de nuestra democracia y el derecho de las personas encarceladas a recibir cuidado pastoral es reconocido en todo el país”.</p><p>Más tarde, el miércoles por la noche, Cupich pidió compasión para aquellos atrapados en la intensificación de la aplicación de la ley de inmigración de la administración de Trump mientras hablaba en la Parroquia de Nuestra Señora del Monte Carmelo en Melrose Park.</p><p>Cupich les dijo a los feligreses que era una noche para “aquellos que conocen la ansiedad de las sombras, el miedo silencioso de un golpe en la puerta, el llanto del dolor callado cuando estás lejos de familiares que no puedes ver”.</p><p>Aludiendo a las cenizas, generalmente un símbolo de arrepentimiento interno y conciencia espiritual, Cupich recordó a los presentes que también era un signo de que eran “ciudadanos de una patria que no tiene fronteras”.</p><p>Estas cenizas “son una declaración de que, sin importar qué leyes cambien, qué digan los políticos o qué incertidumbres enfrenten, todos ustedes son hijos de Dios”, destacó.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" >La Voz Chicago</a></p>
entries.author: Violet Miller

entries.title: Under pressure from feds, University of Chicago cuts ties with program to help students of color get PhDs
entries.summary: <p>The University of Chicago has severed its relationship with a program credited with aiding Black and Brown students to pursue doctoral degrees that the Trump administration alleges is racially discriminatory against white students.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://www.ed.gov/about/news/press-release/us-department-of-educations-office-civil-rights-secures-31-agreements-colleges-and-universities-end-partnerships-phd-project" target="_blank" ><u>According to a Thursday press release</u></a> from the U.S. Department of Education, the University of Chicago is one of 31 colleges nationwide ending its partnership with the PhD Project, an organization launched in 1994 aimed at diversifying the pool of students who pursue post-graduate degrees.</p><p>In a statement, Education Secretary Linda McMahon said she hoped “other institutions with similarly discriminatory practices will follow suit.”</p><p>The University of Chicago said it had ended its relationship with the PhD Project before the school was notified that the federal government was investigating the partnership. In a statement, spokesperson Gerald McSwiggan didn’t say why the university cut ties with the program but noted that it “takes seriously its obligation to prohibit unlawful discrimination.” McSwiggan didn’t immediately respond to follow-up questions.</p><p>The end of these partnerships is yet another example of how the Trump administration has worked to restrict diversity, equity and inclusion efforts at K-12 schools and colleges, though those efforts <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2026/01/21/trump-administration-drops-legal-appeal-over-anti-dei-funding-threat-to-schools-and-colleges" target="_blank" ><u>have not always held up in court</u></a>. Recently, the Education Department <a class="Link" href="https://www.ed.gov/media/document/dear-colleague-letter-sffa-v-harvard-109506.pdf" target="_blank" ><u>ended a controversial directive</u></a> that sought to limit DEI initiatives in education after a federal judge ruled the policy was unlawful.</p><p>Last year, the Education Department’s Office for Civil Rights <a class="Link" href="https://www.ed.gov/about/news/press-release/office-civil-rights-initiates-title-vi-investigations-institutions-of-higher-education" target="_blank" ><u>launched investigations into 45 universities</u></a>, including the University of Chicago, saying they were looking into whether their partnerships with the PhD Project violated the administration’s interpretation of civil rights law because the program “limits eligibility based on the race of participants.”</p><p>After the investigations, the office concluded the schools had violated federal law that prohibits racial discrimination by partnering with the PhD Project. The 31 schools that severed their partnerships also agreed to conduct a review of their work with other organizations to make sure no other programs “restrict participation based on race,” according to the news release.</p><p>Despite losing these universities as partners, the nonprofit PhD Project will continue its work, a spokesperson said in a statement.</p><p>“Our vision is to create a broader talent pipeline of current and future business leaders who are committed to excellence and to each other, through networking, mentorship, and unique events,” the spokesperson wrote. “The PhD Project was founded with the goal of providing more role models in the front of business classrooms and this remains our goal today.”</p><p>Alleging that programs meant to benefit students of color discriminate against white students in higher education has been a theme of Trump’s second term.</p><p>Shortly after taking office last year, Trump took aim at scholarships and other programs designed to bolster Black, Latino and Indigenous students in higher education..</p><p>More recently, the Trump administration <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/10/20/university-illinois-chicago-drops-race-gender-factors-in-faculty-hiring-financial-aid-scholarships" target="_blank" ><u>has offered incentives like more federal funding for colleges</u></a> that sign a contract aligning with Trump’s political priorities, including banning the consideration of race and gender in admissions and hiring.<br></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: How Cubs prepared for rule change leading up to Cactus League opener vs. White Sox
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. – Leading up to the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a>’ Cactus League opener Friday, the players have had the chance to test out the<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/14/could-the-cubs-use-the-new-abs-challenge-system-to-their-advantage-in-2026" > automated ball-strike (ABS) challenge system</a> during live batting practice in Sloan Park this week.</p><p>“Major League Baseball was just setting up the system to make sure it was operational for the spring training games,” Counsell said Tuesday. “And so, took advantage of that.”</p><p>The Cubs’ preparation for the system so far has included live batting practice since Tuesday and an ABS team meeting Thursday morning. They plan to use this spring to experiment with ABS, which is debuting in MLB regular season and postseason games this year, before refining their guidelines on when to challenge.</p><p>“We gave the players just the basics rules [Thursday],” Counsell said. “Like, you’ve got to tap your head, can't just verbalize it – just real basic stuff. And then just go with it, see what happens.”</p><p>The players had fun with it Tuesday. Shortstop Dansby Swanson was the first to challenge and got an ovation from his teammates when he won the appeal.</p><p>The graphic played on the video board, showing the ball flying in from the mound. The camera angle spun around its landing spot outside of the strike zone.</p><p>“I thought it was cool,” Swanson told the Sun-Times. "It's going to be an interesting transition and change.”</p><p>By Thursday, Counsell was also calling out challenges – which he won’t be permitted to do during games – to help test the system further on the eve of the Cubs’ game Friday against the White Sox. Select spring training ballparks were ABS-equipped last year, but Sloan was not.</p><h3>Ballesteros expected ‘soon’</h3><p>Cubs catcher Moisés Ballesteros is expected to join the team this weekend, after his arrival was delayed by visa issues, Counsell said.</p><p>“We're optimistic right now he's going to be here shortly,” Counsell said. “If that should happen, I think we're in a good place. He's going to be behind in terms of when you see him in a game. But with the normal spring training schedule, I feel confident in the number of games we're looking at here.”</p><p>The Cubs have less “firm information” on veteran catcher Christian Bethancourt’s timetable, Counsell said, as he also deals with visa issues.</p><h3>Notes</h3><ul id="rte-587c7042-0de8-11f1-9535-d5d886860bfa"><li>Counsell was encouraged by the carry and velocity on left-hander Shota Imanaga’s fastball Thursday, during a two-inning live batting practice session.</li><li>Left-handed reliever Ryan Rolison was struck above the knee by a line-drive comebacker Thursday while facing right fielder Seiya Suzuki. Rolison finished his inning of live batting practice.</li></ul>
entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Alysa Liu wins figure skating gold to end 24-year Olympic drought for U.S. women
entries.summary: <p>MILAN — Alysa Liu delivered the U.S. its first women's figure skating Olympic gold medal in 24 years, performing a near-flawless free skate on Thursday night in a glittering golden dress to upstage Japanese rivals Kaori Sakamoto and Ami Nakai at the Milan Cortina Games.</p><p>The 20-year-old from the San Francisco Bay Area, who had walked away from the sport after the Beijing Games four years ago only to launch a remarkable comeback, finished with a career-best 226.79 points. Nakai and Sakamoto, skating right behind her, each made a mistake on a combination sequence, and that made the difference in the medals.</p><p>Sakamoto scored 224.90 points to earn a silver to go with her bronze from Beijing. Nakai finished third with 219.16 points.</p><p>The moment Nakai's score was read after the final program of the night, U.S. teammate Amber Glenn jumped up onto the kiss-and-cry stand and raised Liu's hand in triumph. Liu sheepishly turned and applauded the 17-year-old Nakai, who raced over and hugged her.</p><p>It was the first individual gold medal for an American woman since 2002, when Sarah Hughes stood atop the podium in Salt Lake City, and it was the second gold for Liu at the Milan Cortina Games. She helped the Americans win team gold.</p><p>The medal blended right into her gold-sequined dress, only its blue ribbon standing out. And it seemed to be the perfect complement to the golden stripes through her dark brown hair, which are meant to resemble the growth rings on a tree.</p><p>Liu has done a whole lot of growing up over the years.</p><p>She was the youngest U.S. champion ever when she won the first of back-to-back titles at 13 years old. But after finishing sixth at the Beijing Games, Liu was so burned out that she abruptly retired. She spent the next two years doing bucket-list things like climbing up to the base camp of Mount Everest and enrolling at UCLA, where she is studying psychology.</p><p>It was after a skiing trip, when Liu felt the same adrenaline rush that came with skating, that she contemplated her comeback. But this time, she would be skating on her terms, more happy-go-lucky and self-assured than she had been as a childhood prodigy.</p><p>Even during warmups Thursday night, she skated with a grin on her face, never showing any signs of pressure.</p><p>Meanwhile, Glenn finished in fifth place behind Mone Chiba of Japan, a stunning rebound from her disastrous short program Tuesday night. Glenn's season-best free skate gave a score of 214.91 points, and it just about landed her on the podium as well.</p><p>Glenn pumped her first and fought back tears when her score was read, then she took a seat in the new "leader's chair."</p><p>She wound up sitting there for quite a while.</p><p>Adeliia Petrosian, the 18-year-old Russian competing as a neutral athlete at the Milan Cortina Games, tried the only quadruple jump during the women's competition but fell on the quad toe loop. She was clean the rest of the way, but the points Petrosian lost on that fall ended up leaving her less than a half-point behind Glenn in the leader's chair.</p><p>It was Chiba — the ninth skater to follow the three-time U.S. champ — who finally took over first place.</p><p>That didn't last long with Liu next on the ice.</p><p>The reigning world champion — that title was the first for an American in a mere 19 years, by the way — was perfect from her opening triple flip to her closing combination sequence. As the last bits of Donna Summer's rendition of "MacArthur Park" closed, and the roar of the fans filled the void, the carefree Liu gave a casual flip of her ponytail as if to say, "So what?"</p><p>Her coaches, Phillip DiGuglielmo and Massimo Scali, were a little more rambunctious. They punched the air, then gave each other a big hug, before heading over to greet their star pupil when she stepped off the ice to await her score.</p><p>The score that ultimately would give her an Olympic title and end a long drought for the American women.<br></p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: Bears cut LB Amen Ogbongbemiga
entries.summary: <p>The <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> cut linebacker and special teams stalwart Amen Ogbongbemiga on Thursday and saved more than $2 million in the process.</p><p>Ogbongbemiga, who signed a two-year, $5 million deal with the Bears last year, will cost the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/18/bears-make-4-coaching-hires-official-ben-johnson-press-taylor-eric-studesville-will-lawing-isaiah-ford-nfl" target="_blank" >Bears</a> merely a $375,000 dead cap charge next year. He would have counted $2.4 million against the salary cap.</p><p>He was limited to just eight games last year after starting the season on injured reserve because of a knee injury. He played 133 special teams snaps and 82 more at linebacker.</p><p>He played a whopping 84% of the Bears’ special teams downs the year before, however. Ogbongbemiga played 25 games for the Bears in two years after joining the team following a three-year stint with the Chargers.</p><p>The 27-year-old had one start for the Bears. His best defensive game came in Week 12 against the Steelers, when he had 14 tackles after replacing the injured Ruben Hyppolite.</p><p>The Bears currently sit about $3 million above the 2026 salary cap. They must be under it by the start of the league year next month.</p><p>To get there, the Bears could consider cutting Tremaine Edmunds, who had four interceptions last year, the second-most of any NFL linebacker. The savings would be massive — $15 million. In the past, Bears general manager Ryan Poles has released such veterans before the NFL Scouting Combine out of courtesy. The Combine starts Monday.</p><p>Edmunds is due a $1 million roster bonus on the fifth day of the league year.</p><p>The Bears could also simply restructure the contracts of a few veteran players to get under the cap. </p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Can the White Sox carry 3 catchers on its roster?
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — Catchers are a highly valued commodity in baseball — and the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> have squeezed three promising ones onto their roster.</p><p>But how long can that last?</p><p>Teams rarely carry three catchers on a roster throughout a full season, though as injuries can happen, a third option like 27-year-old <b>Korey Lee</b> is a handy fallback.</p><p>But Lee, who played 55 games last year in Triple A and 26 games with the Sox, is out of minor league options. That means if he doesn’t make the Opening Day roster this year, he would have to clear waivers before being sent down to the minors.</p><p>With last year’s arrivals of former prospects <b>Edgar Quero</b>, 22, and <b>Kyle Teel</b>, 24 — and Sox management adamant about both receiving ample experience behind the plate — it almost feels inevitable that someone is the odd man out.</p><p>“The thing that really sticks out is they are all so supportive of each other and work really well together,” Sox manager <b>Will Venable</b> said this week, adding that he’s seen improvements in each of the three defensively. “I know there’s a lot of competition for a roster spot, for playing time. But they have been extremely supportive of each other.”</p><p>Lee said he’s willing to play anywhere in the field — even outfield, if given the chance. But Venable shot down that possibility immediately. “That’s not a path for him in the outfield. … He’s a catcher for us.”</p><p>Teel said the three of them lean on each other in different ways. Lee being the elder of the group, Teel and Quero may look to him for things like daily routine.</p><p>“I feel like there's always that competition. This is the game we play. We're always competing. But it's a great relationship,” said Teel, who will be leaving camp later this month to play in the World Baseball Classic, providing more playing time for Lee.</p><h3><b>Grant Taylor camper of the day</b></h3><p>Hard-throwing right-hander <b>Grant Taylor</b> was lights out in his live pitching session to Sox hitters Thursday.</p><p>After striking out four batters in a row, outfielder <b>Andrew Benintendi</b> finally hit what would have been a bloop single, resulting in resounding cheers from other hitters in the cage. Taylor allowed just soft contact to a couple other batters.</p><p>“[Taylor] looked amazing. Stuff looked really crisp. Just aggressive coming down the mound,” Venable said. “[His stuff] is as good as it gets. Objectively his stuff is I think the best in our organization. He’s a competitor, he’s a guy you like having out there. I think he’s just scratching the surface here.”</p><h3><b>Games begin</b></h3><p>The Sox finally start game action Friday against the Cubs at Sloan Park in Mesa.</p><p>While the final scores don’t matter, most spring training games provide an opportunity for players to face opposing teams in live action and for coaches to see how players are making their adjustments.</p><p>“First couple of games, you are not looking or evaluating too much on the performance. You want to make sure they have a sense of what we are trying to do as far as executing players,” Venable said. “There will be a bunch of things that come up, we will end up addressing and kind of re-correcting. We want to sit back and let them get their feet wet and use the information to help us move forward.”</p><p></p><p></p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: White Sox’ Anthony Kay looks to continue success from Japan
entries.summary: <p>GLENDALE, Ariz. — It’s been a winding road for new <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/white-sox" >White Sox</a> starting pitcher Anthony Kay the last several years.</p><p>Designated for assignment by the Cubs in 2023, a move to Japan, where he developed a new pitch and excelled, and now a return to the U.S. on a two-year, $12 million deal with the other Chicago team.</p><p>“He looks good,” Sox manager Will Venable said. “Just want to get him comfortable and make sure he’s on the same page as the pitching coaches, he’s building up appropriately, healthy first and foremost and support him to go out and do his thing and have a great year.”</p><p>Kay’s biggest setback has been his ability to stay on the mound. He underwent Tommy John surgery soon after the Mets drafted him in the first round in 2016. Then other injuries kept nagging him — back and side discomfort, shoulder discomfort, a blister.</p><p>It led to him fielding only minor league deals from teams after the 2022 season, but he was hoping to pitch in the big leagues. His agent floated the idea of pitching in Japan, so he made the “no-brainer” decision to move overseas in 2023.</p><p>That’s when he bounced back with the Yokohama Bay Stars, posting a 3.42 ERA in his first season. He followed that up with a 1.54 ERA the next season and then finished with a 1.74 ERA last year, good for second best in the Nippon Professional Baseball league, where he crossed paths with new Sox slugger Munetaka Murakami (who hit .400 off Kay but no home runs).</p><p>“Kind of just finding a good routine in between each start and making sure that my body is right for the next one, I think, was the biggest thing that I learned over there in Japan,” Kay said.</p><p>After that success, Kay finds himself a spot in the Sox rotation, which is searching for consistent starters. Last year’s All-Star Shane Smith and the team’s longest-tenured player Davis Martin, are the only other two that have secured a starting role.</p><p>Kay has already talked with teammate Erick Fedde, who took a similar career path when he pitched in Korea and returned in 2024 and provided one of the few bright spots that season for the Sox.</p><p>“I think just seeing the guys before us have success [overseas] … and then came back and had more success, I think that was huge,” Kay said.</p><p>The 30-year-old left hander is using this Spring Training to readjust back to facing MLB hitters. He added a sinker to his arsenal while in Japan, alongside a four-seam fastball, slider, sweeper and a sporadic changeup.</p><p>Hitters in Japan tend to have more flat swings, he noted, making it easier for them to catch up to high fastballs, which led to the development of his sinker.</p><p>“I was sitting behind his bullpen the other day and it’s really, really electric stuff,” said catcher Korey Lee. “[He] knows how to pinpoint some pitches, kind of more of that pitchability type of guy and knows where he’s going to throw it rather than that overpowering stuff. He’s still throwing really, really hard but at the end of the day, it’s more about the location for him rather than the velo and the stuff, and I think that plays on the team really, really well.”</p><p>The White Sox showed great interest in Kay once he indicated a return to the MLB, but Kay said he settled with the Sox because, “You see the plan that they have for everyone.”</p><p>“You see the future and you see all the exciting young talent that all these guys have, and I think it’s a fun time to be part of this organization,” he said. “And I think [we’re] definitely going to either shock some people and I think this team is going to make some noise.”</p><p></p><div class="PageListL" data-module data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true"
