entries.author: Kade Heather

entries.title: CHA sued by Humboldt Park resident over failing to maintain vacant properties
entries.summary: <p>The HOPE Fair Housing Center and a Humboldt Park homeowner are suing the Chicago Housing Authority and two of its property managers for allowing some of its properties in predominantly Black and Hispanic communities to fall into disrepair.</p><p>The lawsuit, filed Feb. 13 in the Circuit Court of Cook County, accuses the housing authority, Hispanic Housing Development Corp. and Manage Chicago of “longstanding and systemic failure to adequately lease, maintain, and secure its scattered site portfolio.” It alleges these issues violate state human and civil rights laws and serve as public and private nuisances.</p><p>“These failures have produced profound and disproportionate harms for residents of predominantly Black and Hispanic neighborhoods,” the lawsuit said.</p><p>The filing follows a two-year investigation by HOPE that found vacancy rates and duration, exterior maintenance and physical deficiencies at CHA properties were worse in Black and Hispanic neighborhoods compared to majority white communities. These conditions led units to deteriorate and contributed to neighborhood destabilization, the investigation found.</p><p>The housing authority has 2,800 scattered units, with more than 450 sitting vacant. Of those vacant units, approximately 78% are located in communities of color, the lawsuit said. The CHA is the largest single owner of rental housing in the city.</p><p>Scattered units are small- to mid-sized apartment buildings and single-family homes. In 2023, the agency announced a push to renovate its <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/11/27/23975023/cha-property-renovation-restore-home-program-tracey-scott-scattered-sites" >scattered sites portfolio</a>.</p><p>The Illinois Answers Project and Block Club Chicago published an <a class="Link" href="https://blockclubchicago.org/2023/11/29/as-city-battles-housing-shortage-cha-lets-hundreds-of-empty-homes-decay/" target="_blank" >investigation</a> in 2023 about the CHA’s chronic vacancy issues with scattered site units. The CHA’s inspector general office also reported in recent years on the agency’s inappropriate maintenance of the properties, including its failure to comply with the city’s vacant buildings ordinance by registering, securing and maintaining the properties.</p><p>“These properties should be maintained at a standard worthy of the communities they exist in — and that standard still applies when those communities are Black and Latine,” Josefina Navar, deputy director at HOPE Fair Housing Center, said in a Wednesday news release. “Every day that a unit sits abandoned or in disrepair is a major disservice to both these communities and the thousands of families lingering on the waiting lists for housing.”</p><p>The CHA’s waitlist numbers in the thousands for its housing programs, with some applicants waiting up to decades.</p><p>CHA spokesperson Matthew Aguilar said the agency hasn’t been formally served with the lawsuit and can’t comment on pending litigation.</p><p>Manage Chicago CEO Chris Amatore said in a statement that many of the incidents mentioned in the lawsuit predate his company’s involvement. The property management firm took over in July 2025.</p><p>“Since assuming responsibility, we have operated within the scope of our contractual authority with CHA regarding maintenance and security matters,” Amatore said.</p><p>He declined to comment further, citing the pending litigation.</p><p>Hispanic Housing Development declined to comment and said it hasn’t been formally served with the lawsuit.</p><p>Humboldt Park resident and plaintiff Caroline Bermudez has lived next to a CHA property at 849 N. St. Louis Ave., which has been vacant for nearly a decade, according to the suit. The single-family home was previously managed by Hispanic Housing and is now operated by Manage Chicago.</p><p>Bermudez experienced “persistent disruptive activity, found used drug paraphernalia in her yard, and endured repeated incidents that made her home environment unlivable and unsafe,” according to the lawsuit. The property’s conditions, described as a “stash house with significant narcotics activity,” led her and her partner to temporarily relocate to live with family for more than a year, due to safety concerns. While they were gone, people broke into their house and left a stolen vehicle with a loaded firearm inside her garage, according to the suit. She’s now back in her home, despite continued issues.</p><p>She brought her complaint to HOPE, which spurred its investigation. Bermudez and her neighbors reported the issues to city agencies, law enforcement and the CHA, according to the suit.</p><p>“I’m angry because I had to relocate out of the house because the city and CHA have refused to do anything,” Bermudez told the Sun-Times. “It is a systemic failure on multiple levels.”</p><p>As for the lawsuit, Bermudez hopes the CHA makes the home next door habitable for a family in need.</p><p>“I call on city officials — the City Council and the mayor — to finally hold CHA accountable for its negligent practices,” Bermudez said.</p><p>The mayor’s office didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.</p><p>The new discrimination lawsuit is salt in the wound for the embattled housing authority, as it scrambles to address a recent <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/02/11/cha-hud-federal-disability-civil-rights-laws-ada-whistleblower-complaint" >whistleblower complaint</a> alleging dysfunction of the agency’s reasonable accommodations process for residents with disabilities.</p><p>Records show the CHA violated federal disability laws and the civil rights of residents for at least eight years — leading to negotiations for a voluntary compliance agreement between the CHA and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2026/02/11/cha-hud-federal-disability-civil-rights-laws-ada-whistleblower-complaint" >CHA has violated disability, civil rights laws for years, whistleblower and HUD say</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/the-watchdogs/2025/11/15/cha-residents-frustrated-housing-agency-permanent-ceo" >CHA residents grow frustrated as agency marks one year without permanent CEO</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p></p>
entries.author: Lizzie Kane

entries.title: Rutherford Wilson, Chicago police officer and businessman, dies at 87
entries.summary: <p></p><p></p><p></p><p>On a wall of his Chatham home, a series of newspaper clippings, commendations and photos tell the story of Rutherford Wilson, a former violent crimes detective sergeant with the Chicago Police Department.</p><p>There was the time in 1990, when a stray bullet hit 10-year-old Robert Jones in the face at a public housing facility on the South Side. Jones lost his sight and while recovering found an interest in music.</p><p>Mr. Wilson heard the story and purchased a piano and had it delivered to his home as an anonymous gift.</p><p>Jones became a professional musician. His story was told in multiple appearances on "The Oprah Winfrey Show."</p><p>Mr. Wilson visited Jones after the shooting to share some encouraging words.</p><p>"He told me that I can still do anything I set my mind to, and there's a place for me in this world," recalled Jones, now 46. </p><p>Jones didn't learn until years after the shooting that the piano was a gift from Mr. Wilson.</p><p>"It just shows you the big heart he had, he didn't want it to be about him, he wanted it to be about me and helping me. Music is what basically carried me through those tough times," Jones said.</p><p>"Rutherford was retiring that year, and in lieu of throwing a retirement party for himself, he took that money and bought the piano," said his wife, Wanza Wilson. "He was so moved by that boy's story."</p><p>Mr. Wilson, who was on the police force for 28 years, died Jan. 17 from natural causes. He was 87.</p><p>He saw early in his police career how bad things could get.</p><p>He was one of the first officers on the scene after Richard Speck killed eight student nurses who roomed together at a South Side townhouse in 1966. After Speck fled, a ninth roommate emerged from her hiding place under a bed, climbed out a window and began screaming for help. The crime shocked the country.</p><p>Years later, in 1992, Mr. Wilson had a close encounter with a serial killer.</p><p>Mr. Wilson had just emerged from a South Side grocery store when three men robbed him of his pager and cash. Mr. Wilson quickly had the pager deactivated and got a new one with the same number. He then intercepted calls to the pager intended for the robbers and spoke with a girl whom Mr. Wilson persuaded to provide him with the name of one of the men who robbed him: Ralph Harris.</p><p>Harris was charged with the robbery and while out on parole and awaiting trial in the summer of 1992 committed four murders.</p><p>Mr. Wilson was also a businessman who owned and operated five motels — four on the South Side and one on the West Side.</p><p>"He would get those motels and clean them up," recalled his wife, noting that Mr. Wilson had three other partners in the venture, including one other Chicago police detective. "Some of them were vice ridden to begin with, and these young detectives took a chance with the investment, and Rutherford promised his supervisors that they were coming in there to clean the businesses up and they'd be reputable, and they did."</p><p>He hired dozens of people from the community to work at the motels, his wife said.</p><p>"He loved this neighborhood, and people respected him because he was doing good, and he loved being a police officer and catching the bad guy," his wife said.</p><p>Retired Chicago police officer Thomas Wortham III said Mr. Wilson was there for him after one of the darkest times in his life.</p><p>In 2010, outside his Chatham home, Wortham's son, Thomas Wortham IV, was shot and killed by thieves who tried to steal his motorcycle.</p><div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Rutherford Wilson with his wife, Wanza Wilson</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Provided</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Mr. Wilson was part of a group of community members who came together to build a playground honoring his son.</p><p>"He was in his 70s and helping lift sod into a wheelbarrow on a hot day. It just blew me away. He didn't have to do that," recalled Wortham.</p><p>For years, Mr. Wilson hosted a monthly "pool party" at his home where retired police officers, judges, businessmen, politicians and other city workers gathered to shoot billiards and commiserate.</p><p>"Integrity was his thing," said friend and business partner Willie David Walker. "He was the kind of guy you want to have as a policeman."</p><p>Mr. Wilson was born April 19, 1938, to Smith Daniel Wilson and Rachel Rutherford Wilson. His father was a World War I veteran who worked as a prohibition officer for the federal government during Prohibition and later became a postal worker. His mother was a nurse.</p><p>Mr. Wilson played football at Marshall High School, attended Roosevelt University and was a member of the Phi Beta Sigma fraternity.</p><p>"We loved to travel together, all over the world, and he loved sports, but I could beat him in tennis," his wife said.</p><p>In addition to his wife, Mr. Wilson is survived by his sister, Florence Pothin; his daughters Cynthia Wilson, Kathleen Wilson, Asanta Maxwell, Simone Rodriguez and Carlise Maxwell; and his sons Dwayne Johnson and Brian Wilson;12 grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren. He is predeceased by his daughter Elizabeth White.</p><p>Services have been held.</p>
entries.author: Mitch Dudek

entries.title: Why Blackhawks goalie Spencer Knight believes an illness gave him valuable experience
entries.summary: <p>During the final week before the Olympic break, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a> goalie Spencer Knight was battling through a tough-to-shake illness.</p><p>He was getting chills on the ice and couldn't really speak, which hampered him as a <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/12/11/blackhawks-spencer-knight-voice-blind-spot-detection-louis-crevier-defensemen" target="_blank" >vocal goalie</a> who frequently yells instructions to his defensemen.</p><p>Hawks coach Jeff Blashill's usual policy with illnesses, however, is to ask the individual player if he feels capable of giving 100% effort despite not internally feeling 100%. In Knight's case, he believed he could, so he started both of the Hawks' last two games against the Sharks and Blue Jackets.</p><p>He believed he could for perhaps the most Knightian reasons imaginable, too, considering all the Hawks have come to know about his thorough, philosophical and sometimes superhuman approach to life and hockey.</p><p>"I don't like speaking things into existence, and I saw it as a test," Knight said Thursday. "The way I look at it is ... putting yourself in different situations is how you're going to learn.</p><p>"Learning how to navigate not feeling well at all physically — and learning how to play with that — is really valuable going into the future. If there's times where you have to play — or maybe you're in the playoffs — you've got to figure something out. For me, it gives me more experience, which is good. I want to grab as much experience as I can."</p><p>He believes his immune system was weakened by a delayed Hawks flight the week before that didn't arrive in Pittsburgh until nearly 3 a.m., and he would like to see the NHL shift more toward flying the morning after games rather than overnight. But that's a topic for another day.</p><p>The Olympic break did turn out to be perfectly timed, giving him time to get back to true 100%. He relaxed with friends and family in Connecticut and Massachusetts and then escaped to the beaches of Florida, where he also got lunch with Panthers goalie and longtime mentor Sergei Bobrovsky.</p><p>The value of this February rest has been much-discussed in regards to the Hawks' plethora of rookie forwards and defensemen, but it makes sense it would be even more valuable for their goalies. Knight's <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/11/30/blackhawks-nhl-goalie-spencer-knight-off-ice-habits-red-light-mat" target="_blank" >unique off-ice habits</a> designed to maximize his health and recovery can only do so much.</p><p>Although Knight isn't a rookie, this is his first season as a full-time starter in the NHL, and that experience has been eye-opening. He has already made 39 starts this season, compared to 36, 0, 19 and 27 starts in each of the last four seasons.</p><p>"I've been able to be really intentional observing and anticipating things [to figure out] what to expect," he said. "But there's still situations you don't expect, right? And you just learn how to go [with it]. <i>... </i>Whatever I have in that moment before the game, that's what I've got. I'll just do what I can."</p><p>Knight raced out of the gates this season with a splendid .924 save percentage and plus-12.8 GSAA in his first 15 starts. He led the league in GSAA and led full-time starters in save percentage at that point (Nov. 24).</p><p>But since then, he has been only a league-average goalie, posting an .895 save percentage and minus-0.1 GSAA over his last 24 starts. (The league average save percentage of .896 this season is the lowest since 1993-94.)</p><p>He still sits in the top 10 in total GSAA, but it would be great to see him finish this breakout season with a hot stretch run. That would likely have a snowball effect on the Hawks' overall team success and morale.</p><p>He said he's not working on anything specific technique-wise right now, but he plans to evaluate that in April. He likes to keep skating immediately after the season and then take a break later in the summer instead of taking it right away.</p><p></p><p></p><p></p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" entries.author: Ben Pope

entries.title: Cubs core aiming to achieve 'something really special' in 2026 with possible roster overhaul looming
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. — There’s some sense of deja vu this spring, as core members of this <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" >Cubs</a> team field questions about their expiring contracts, without any sign of impending extension news.</p><p>“I've talked with some of the other guys who are on their last years,” right-hander Jameson Taillon said last week. “And I think we're all just embracing this year as, we have the chance to do something really special together, and who knows if we'll all be back next year.”</p><p>It’s not a perfect comparison to 2021, when Anthony Rizzo, Kris Bryant and Javy Báez went into the season without extensions, and were all traded in a stunning deadline teardown. But if the Cubs don’t come to extension agreements with any of their walk-year players, they’ll be facing a roster overhaul this offseason, affecting the lineup, rotation and bullpen.</p><p>Cubs president of baseball operations Jed Hoyer has pointed out the advantages of financial flexibility after this season. But with the current collective bargaining agreement expiring on Dec. 1, if the owners lock out the players — <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/18/mlb-players-association-bracing-for-lockout-before-2027-season-all-but-guaranteed-bruce-meyer-executive-director" >as MLB players association interim executive director Bruce Meyer said he expects</a> — the timeline to pull off that overhaul could be tight.</p><p>“Both on a position player level and pitching level, we have a lot of free agents,” Hoyer said at the start of spring training. “It's going to be a topic of conversation, there's no question, with those free agents. I think we look at it as, players need to focus on right now, focus on this team.”</p><p>The front office, however, is looking ahead. Hoyer and his group knew this was coming. It was somewhat by design, as they kept the end of the CBA in mind while structuring multi-year deals.</p><p>Of the group, the three everyday hitters — left fielder Ian Happ, second baseman Nico Hoerner and right fielder Seiya Suzuki are the longest tenured. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/02/16/cubs-chairman-tom-ricketts-on-potential-mlb-broadcast-consolidation-we-love-our-independence" >Happ and Suzuki said Monday</a> that the Cubs have not initiated extension talks. Hoerner declined to comment on the subject of contract negotiations.</p><p>“There's plenty of guys that are on their last year here,” Hoerner said. “That's also an opportunity, though, because we've been fortunate to play as a group for a while. It creates excitement in that you don't get to share a locker room with guys in a consistent core a lot in the big leagues. And so to have that opportunity, to have gotten better, and to now be in a place where we can really seize that opportunity is super exciting.”</p><p>The Cubs will at least retain shortstop Dansby Swanson, whose seven-year deal runs through 2029, and third baseman Alex Bregman, who signed a five-year deal this offseason, offering veteran leadership past this season. </p><p>But the Cubs could lose three important pieces to their lineup. Suzuki provides a power threat near the top of the order. Switch-hitting Happ’s knack for getting on base makes him a steadying presence, regardless of whether he’s on a hot or cool streak. Hoerner’s contact ability and clutch performance play whether he’s leading off or hitting in the bottom half of the lineup.</p><p>Hoerner could hit the free agent market as a shortstop, a premium position that comes with higher earning potential. Happ should benefit from a thin outfield class. And Suzuki’s bat will be seen as an asset, whether teams evaluate him as a long-term outfielder or designated hitter.</p><p>Happ and Suzuki both expressed an openness to extension negotiations.</p><p>“I want to work hard and perform well,” Suzuki said through interpreter Edwin Stanberry, “and hopefully they say, yes.”</p><p>As far as extension candidates go, pitching tends to be more volatile, which will factor in as the Cubs decide whether to jump the market. This past winter, for example, they chose not to pick up left-hander Shota Imanaga’s three-year team option. A good season with an uptick in velocity could at least alter the calculation as Imanaga plays out his one-year qualifying offer.</p><p>Left-hander Matthew Boyd ($15 million mutual option for 2027) and Taillon could also hit free agency after this season.</p><p>“We do have three free-agent starters, but I think that's something that we'll continue to discuss throughout the spring and throughout the season,” Hoyer said. “But I think having that next wave take a step forward will be really helpful, and something that's a big priority.”</p><p>The Cubs, however, aren’t in position to fill all three spots with only internal options — unless they’re comfortable with their rotation taking a step back.</p><p>Catcher Carson Kelly, 31, also has a mutual option ($7.5 million) for 2027. And per usual, the Cubs’ bullpen is stacked with players on short-term contracts, necessitating the Cubs’ normal offseason restocking.</p><p>“Every player's got a situation,” manager Craig Counsell said. “And, frankly, if you're at the point where you're in a free agent year, you're doing pretty good, things have gone pretty well for you. So, it's this team. It's now.”</p><p></p><bsp-listcarousel class="PageListE" data-module data-column-count=3 data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-hide-descriptions="true" entries.author: Maddie Lee

entries.title: Ex-ComEd executive caught up in bribery scheme avoids prison after testifying against Madigan, others
entries.summary: <p>Fidel Marquez may not have been the architect of the vast ComEd bribery scheme that brought down former Illinois House Speaker <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/madigan-trial-news" target="_blank" >Michael J. Madigan</a>.</p><p>But the utility executive still sensed the moral danger.</p><p>He knew that pleasing a powerful politician by hiring his allies<b> </b>for do-nothing jobs was wrong, a prosecutor said Thursday. So when the FBI gave Marquez the opportunity to put things right in January 2019, he took it — and wore a wire <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/3/30/23663522/key-federal-witness-comed-bribery-trial-pays-a-price-defense-grills-his-decision-his-personal-life" target="_blank" >against his friends and colleagues</a>.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/madigan-trial-news/mike-madigan-guilty-verdict" >Once a political giant, Madigan now a convicted felon and likely prison inmate — but not a racketeer</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>That decision also spared him any prison time. U.S. District Judge Mary Rowland agreed Thursday to give Marquez only two years of probation and a<b> </b>$50,000 fine for his role in the scheme.</p><p>But first, she made one thing clear: “We need people like you to stand up sooner.”</p><p>“If we can’t have ComEd stand up to this stuff, we are sunk,” Rowland said. “We’re in real trouble if we don’t have powerful entities saying ‘enough’ to unreasonable, corrupt politicians.”</p><p>The low-key, 75-minute sentencing of Marquez seemed to finally close the book — in the lower courts, anyway — on the blockbuster corruption investigation that upended Chicago politics and led to prison sentences <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/politics/2025/06/13/mike-madigan-sentencing-hearing" target="_blank" >for Madigan</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2024/06/24/ed-burke-trial-alderman-edward-m-burke-news-verdict-sentence-final" target="_blank" >ex-Chicago Ald. Edward M. Burke</a>.</p><p>There was little suspense, though, as prosecutors had agreed in 2020 to seek probation if Marquez continued his cooperation. The main point of contention in Thursday’s hearing revolved around whether Marquez should pay a fine as high as $250,000, and whether he should be ordered to perform 320 hours of community service.</p><p>In the end, Rowland ordered Marquez to pay a fraction of the fine sought by prosecutors. She also spared him any court-ordered community service. Christopher Niewoehner, his defense attorney, said Marquez already spent “at least” 336 hours in 2025 helping students at Pima Community College in Arizona, where he lives.</p><div class="Enhancement" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Fidel Marquez at the Dirksen Federal Courthouse for sentencing on Feb. 19, 2026.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Candace Dane Chambers / Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Still, the light sentence came after Marquez testified in two trials against five people who now sit in federal prison: Madigan, former ComEd lobbyists <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/07/24/madigans-political-fixer-gets-2-year-prison-sentence" target="_blank" >Michael McClain</a> and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/07/14/ex-comed-lobbyist-john-hooker-gets-18-month-prison-sentence" target="_blank" >John Hooker</a>, ex-ComEd CEO <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/07/21/former-comed-ceo-gets-2-year-prison-sentence" target="_blank" >Anne Pramaggiore</a> and onetime City Club President <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/08/05/ex-city-club-president-gets-1-year-prison-sentence-in-comed-scheme" target="_blank" >Jay Doherty</a>.</p><p>The only person caught up in the scandal who seemed to fare better was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-corruption-trials/2025/04/04/danny-solis-federal-prosecutors-bribery-dirksen-courthouse" target="_blank" >Danny Solis</a>. The former Chicago City Council member — who wore a wire against Madigan, Burke and others — struck a deal that helped him avoid even a criminal conviction.</p><p>But while Solis has <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2022/4/21/23036288/danny-solis-deal-cooperation-truly-extraordinary-bribery-charge" target="_blank" >previously been described</a> as one of Chicago’s “most significant cooperators in the last several decades,” prosecutors on Thursday heaped praise upon Marquez for his role in ending the ComEd conspiracy.</p><p>Assistant U.S. Attorney Timothy Chapman even suggested Marquez, who rose to become ComEd’s senior vice president of governmental affairs, deserved to be known as a “super cooperator.”</p><p>“It is simply difficult to describe in words how important and powerful that cooperation was,” Chapman said.</p><p>Niewoehner, a former federal prosecutor, compared Marquez to influence peddler Stuart Levine, a crucial cooperator caught up in the investigation that snared ex-Gov. Rod Blagojevich more than a decade ago.</p><p>“I think when you sentence Mr. Marquez, he truly is the most extraordinary cooperator in the living memory, I think, of the U.S. attorney’s office,” Niewoehner told the judge.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/madigan-trial-news/2024/11/05/former-comed-exec-wore-wire-takes-stand-michael-madigan-trial" >Key witness testifies ComEd funneled more than $600,000 to Madigan allies to get bills passed</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>When the FBI confronted Marquez at his mother’s home in Hammond, Indiana, on Jan. 16, 2019, he “made an immediate decision to help because he thought it was the right thing to do,” Niewoehner said.</p><p>“It was a chance for him to stop something he thought was wrong,” the attorney said.</p><p>Marquez gathered much of the feds’ most crucial evidence without the assistance of a lawyer, Niewoehner wrote in a recent court memo.<b> </b>The attorney said Marquez didn’t find counsel until after May 2019, once he’d secretly recorded McClain, Pramaggiore, Hooker and Doherty.</p><p>Marquez testified during Madigan’s trial that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/madigan-trial-news/2024/11/05/former-comed-exec-wore-wire-takes-stand-michael-madigan-trial" target="_blank" >ComEd funneled cash to Madigan’s allies</a> over several years as a “favor” so that Madigan would be “more positively disposed toward ComEd’s legislative agenda.”</p><p>Madigan’s trial ended in February 2025, with jurors agreeing that the former speaker conspired to have ComEd officials pay $1.3 million to his allies as part of the scheme.</p><p>McClain, Pramaggiore, Hooker and Doherty <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2023/5/2/23697452/jurors-reach-verdict-in-comed-bribery-trial" target="_blank" >were convicted by a separate jury</a> in May 2023 for their roles in the plot.</p><p>U.S. District Judge John Blakey sentenced Madigan last summer to 7 ½ years in prison. The once-powerful Democrat is serving his sentence in West Virginia. However, he’s challenging his conviction, and the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals is set to hear arguments in his case April 9.</p><p>U.S. District Judge Manish Shah gave McClain and Pramaggiore two-year prison sentences. He gave Hooker 18 months and Doherty one year.</p><p>McClain and Pramaggiore are also pursuing an appeal, and arguments in their case are set for April 14.</p>
entries.author: Jon Seidel

entries.title: Chinatown students ring in the Year of the Horse with dragons, drums and dance
entries.summary: <p>The sound of drums echoed through the gymnasium of St. Therese Chinese Catholic School in Chinatown on Thursday as students began their celebration marking the start of the Lunar New Year. </p><p>The school's annual performance is an opportunity for students to showcase their talents while learning more about Chinese culture with their classmates. </p><p>"We're so proud of our culture," the school's principal Lisa Oi said. "You really don't have to be Chinese or Asian to really appreciate it. As you can see, all of our children love to participate in it." </p><p>The Lunar New Year, which began on Tuesday, is a centuries-old tradition that marks the end of winter and the start of a new year with a new moon. Year of the Horse celebrations will last 15-days — until March 3.</p><p>Preparations for Thursday's performance started months ago. Students from pre-kindergarten to eighth grade worked with music teachers and choreographers to bring the event to life. Oi said she watched as students grew more confident with their routines as they rehearsed. </p><p>"If you saw them in August, they do not want anything to do with that stage," Oi said. "But now, they're just, like, little stage lovers."</p><p>As the the drums fell silent in the gymnasium, student voices picked up in excitement, ready for what was to come. </p><p>An orange dragon began circling around the perimeter of the space. Students operating the dragon strategically paced their steps to make the puppet look like was alive. Students danced around the stage holding red silk fans that symbolized wishes for prosperity, health and success in the coming year. Early learners — as young as three and four-years-old — performed the Bianpao dance with firecrackers to bring good luck and drive away bad fortune. </p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> aria-label="Next"> <svg class="FlickityCustomNavigation-button-icon"><use xlink:href="#icon-right"></use></svg> </button> </div> </div></div> </bsp-carousel> </div> </div><p>One student, first-grader Logan Lin, took center stage as he performed in the Yong Qi "courage" dance alongside his classmates. Lin and his classmates wore traditional red garments and danced around the stage in a choreographed routine.</p><p>Lin said he was "very excited" to dance with his class. </p><p>It was a whole school effort, said Joe Delfin, the school's music teacher. </p><p>"Fortunately, our students are professionals," Delfin said. </p><p>Delfin said he has watched alumni, who used to be performers in the annual celebration, return to the show with their kids.</p><p>"They're starting their own traditions," he said. "We hope that these students will really appreciate their culture and share it with their neighbors, friends and their families as well."<br></p>
